title: What 5 Wall Street heavyweights expect for markets and the economy in the 2nd half of 2025
content: The second half of the year should offer more clarity on the impact of tariffs on the economy, as the data begins to fully ... is anticipating a smoother end to 2025. "President Trump is like a new ...
resumen:
Investors faced a volatile 2025 as the S&P 500 tipped into bear market territory and rebounded. Recession risks have decreased with lower tariffs, but geopolitical tensions remain a concern.

Wall Street strategists predict more volatility in the next six months. The July 9 tariff deadline looms large, and President Donald Trump's "Big Beautiful Bill" is slowly taking shape. The Trump-Powell feud continues, and geopolitical risks are still on the radar.

**Morgan Stanley:**

*   Mike Wilson, the bank's chief investment officer, anticipates a smoother end to 2025.
*   Morgan Stanley believes the market bottomed during the Liberation Day sell-off.
*   The bank's year-end target for the S&P 500 is 6,500.

**JPMorgan:**

*   Hussein Malik, the bank's head of global research, believes a recession is unlikely.
*   The bank expects rates to be higher for longer and sees the Fed cutting 100 basis points between December and the spring of 2026 — arriving at a terminal Fed funds rate of 3.5%.
*   JPMorgan expects the S&P 500 to end the year at 6,000.

**Wells Fargo:**

*   Darrell Cronk, the bank's chief investment officer, believes markets shouldn't over-worry about the economic outlook.
*   Wells Fargo has a year-end S&P 500 target of 5,900-6,100.

**Goldman Sachs Asset Management:**

*   Greg Calnon, co-head of public investing, anticipates a couple of rate cuts later this year.
*   The bank expects the stock market to continue broadening beyond the Magnificent Seven.

**Bank of America:**

*   Claudio Irigoyen, head of the bank's Global Economics Research, believes the US economy will remain resilient.
*   Bank of America sees inflation peaking at 3.1%.
*   Irigoyen is betting on no rate cuts at all this year.

title: The success of Southeast Asia’s tilt to Europe depends on commitment to regional reform and global openness
content: Southeast Asia's transition to a high-income region is dependent on external partnerships to defend rules-based trade and internal reforms to increase domestic competitiveness ...
resumen:
The 2025 ISEAS State of Southeast Asia report shows that ASEAN elites are deeply concerned about geopolitical tensions between the United States and China. The European Union is now overtaking the United States to become the region's second most trusted partner after Japan. Deeper engagement between the EU and ASEAN has great potential due to their shared interests in trade and international value chains. To achieve long-term prosperity, Southeast Asia must preserve open markets, pursue domestic reforms to strengthen competitiveness and leverage relationships with the EU and other partners to defend rules-based trade.

The recently published ISEAS Yusof-Ishak Institute’s 2025 State of Southeast Asia report provides a useful temperature check on how the region’s political, private sector, media and civil society thinkers see the state of the region. Tensions between the United States and China have left Southeast Asia wondering about where reliable economic and strategic partners might be found. Japan has consolidated its lead as the most trusted nation in Southeast Asia. The United States has fallen in the rankings, losing its second place to the European Union.

The European Union represents a very different mode of regional cooperation compared to the ASEAN model. ASEAN emphases consensus and the importance of national sovereignty. The EU has always been predicated on a federalist logic that has seen national governments give up some sovereignty in the name of exceptionally deep economic and political integration.

Political cooperation in ASEAN has accompanied major economic integration and the growth of sophisticated international value chains, the viability of which depends on a stable and predictable trade regime. A major trade war between China and the United States would have been enough to cause major damage to these value chains. President Trump threatened many Southeast Asian countries with so-called ‘reciprocal’ tariffs – ruled illegal last month by a US court.

Deepening cooperation between Europe and Southeast Asia seems like a no-brainer. For Southeast Asia, Europe offers the prospect of a major developed market. There is an appetite in European capitals for renewed attention to the new centre of world economic gravity in Asia. European leaders are getting better at talking to Southeast Asia, making sure to stress ASEAN centrality at least in rhetoric.

The EU seems like a natural alternative partner for Southeast Asia. A more ambitious possibility would be for the EU to make an agreement with CPTPP members that encompassed both liberalisation but also an agreement to jointly push for WTO reform. The EU and ASEAN should take the time to build common ground on the maintenance of the open global trading order, without which neither region can prosper.

Southeast Asia cannot depend on making new friends to find its way through the challenges of the international environment it now finds itself in. Trade diversion from American tariffs on China will lead to a substantial flow of cheap Chinese manufactured goods to Southeast Asia. Open trade has built Southeast Asia’s prosperity.

The response to the challenge is really about domestic reform in Southeast Asia. The main game for Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia and the other regional economies lies in building competitive domestic markets for goods, for labour and for capital that can support a process of continual quality upgrading. This will enable Southeast Asian economies to further push into European-focused global value chains.

These developments are only possible because of the existence of open, predictable trading rules that the European Union has mostly respected. Southeast Asian leadership in protecting the foundations of the global trading regime is still as important as ever.

Southeast Asia’s transition to a high-income region is dependent on the success of that agenda.

title: A multipolar world, a vulnerable Sri Lanka
content: As the global order undergoes sweeping shifts, with geopolitics, trade tensions, and macroeconomic uncertainty converging, small economies such as Sri Lanka find themselves at a critical crossroads. .
resumen:
The article discusses the challenges Sri Lanka faces in a shifting global order.

Prof. Razeen Sally, a senior economist, and Daily Mirror Business Editor Shabiya Ali Ahlam discussed the current state of geopolitics, the global economic trajectory, and the impact on Sri Lanka.

Prof. Sally describes the current state of geopolitics as a structural shift from relative order and stability to increasing disorder, with a reduced American willingness and capacity to provide global public goods. He notes the rise of China and the weakness of other players like the EU and the UK, leading to a multipolar world.

He predicts a shift from predictability to unpredictability, volatility, and a loss of confidence in the global economy. The IMF predicts global growth will fall to about 2.3 percent this year, possibly rising to 2.5 percent next year and the year after, which is significantly lower than the pre-pandemic average. Developing countries are expected to be more affected.

The article also discusses the emergence of economic nationalism and mercantilism, with protectionism becoming the norm. Prof. Sally suggests that countries should liberalize as much as possible.

He foresees that external shocks, such as trade wars or a surge in oil prices, could tip Sri Lanka into another recession. He outlines three scenarios for Sri Lanka: drift, relapse, and sustainable growth. He believes that Sri Lanka is not doing enough to achieve sustainable growth. He notes that the government has the right intentions but lacks a clear understanding of the required structural reforms.

title: Trump tariffs live updates: Trump sees no need to extend July 9 deadline; Canada scraps tech tax
content: As earning season approaches, Goldman Sachs (GS) said on Monday that US profit margins will be tested as investors await to see how President Trump's war has hurt companies ... risk breaching World ...
resumen: President Donald Trump said he did not plan to extend the July 9 tariff deadline he set for countries to broker deals with the US. He added: "I could, no big deal.” During a White House press conference on Friday, Trump said the July 9 deadline to raise "reciprocal" tariffs was not set. Late on Sunday, Canada cancelled its digital services tax on US technology companies, such as Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), just hours before it was set to start. Canada's finance ministry said Prime Minister Mark Carney and Trump will resume negotiations to reach a deal by July 21. Trump said on Friday he was cutting off trade talks with Canada and threatened to set a new tariff rate on the country's goods within the next week. The US and China stepped closer to a full tariff and trade deal, making a pact to formally cement the informal trade understanding reached in Geneva talks in May. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent hinted at progress on US talks with its most important partners. So far, Trump has only firmed up one signed trade deal with the United Kingdom. Canada scrapped its planned digital services tax on US tech firms late Sunday. The move aims to revive stalled trade talks with the US, which halted on Friday over the tax, with President Trump calling it a "blatant attack." Canada's finance ministry said Prime Minister Mark Carney and Trump plan to reach a deal by July 21. Trump warned on Friday he would set new tariffs on Canadian goods within a week. The 3% tech tax would have hit firms like Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG), and Amazon (AMZN), but Canada will now bring forward legislation to cancel it. Tariffs pressures have started to hit goods, with prices on products made in China sold on Amazon (AMZN) rising faster than overall inflation, according to 1,400 different items which were analysed by DataWeave and provided exclusively to Reuters. The European Union is pushing back against the US and its criticism of the bloc's tech rules. There is a belief among economists that President Trump's tariffs will help boost inflation over the next few months. South Korea is looking for an extension to the July 9 tariff deadline as talks continue. The US has raised concerns over non-tariff barriers and broader defence. China and the US reached a deal to resume rare earth exports in London this month. The US and China reached a deal to resume rare earth exports in London this month, resolving delays in implementing the Geneva agreement, which was established in May. The US-UK trade deal was cemented at the G-7 Summit this month. Japan is seeking exemption from US auto tariffs, which currently stand at 25%, while also facing a new 24% reciprocal tariff from July 9. The US and Mexico are negotiating a quota deal to reduce Trump's 50% steel tariffs. Goldman Sachs (GS) said on Monday that US profit margins will be tested as investors await to see how President Trump's war has hurt companies. Goldman's David Kostin said Q2 earnings will show the immediate impact of tariffs, which have risen about 10% this year. Nike (NKE) rose 15% after announcing it will offset higher duties. Despite predictions from members of President Trump's administration that it could complete "90 deals in 90 days," the White House doesn't appear to be anywhere close to the sweeping global trade reform it was seeking, Bloomberg reports. President Donald Trump he did not think he would need to extend a July 9 tariffs deadline. The fireworks used in displays across the US likely won't be affected by President Trump's tariffs. The market's task of planning for how tariff developments will play out this summer got more complicated Friday as President Trump and his team offered a host of options for what to expect in the months ahead. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent suggested that his focus could be on an end-of-summer deadline. Trump offered multiple other scenarios during a wide-ranging press conference. Trump reiterated his plan to send letters to dictate tariff rates for at least some countries, perhaps as soon as next week. Trump said that a July 9 deadline to raise "reciprocal" tariffs is not set and perhaps could move, but in an unpredictable direction. President Trump on Friday said he is cutting off all trade talks with Canada, threatening to set a new tariff rate on goods imported from the country within the next week. The reason, according to Trump: Canada's plan to implement a digital services tax, which could affect US tech companies. The US and China cemented the trade truce first agreed to last month in Geneva. President Trump touted tariff revenue and an influx of domestic manufacturing but offered few details on the state of tariff negotiations ahead of the July 9 deadline, when the tariff pause expires. The Trump administration has confirmed preliminary trade agreements with China and the UK. Trump again teased a potential deal with India. US and EU officials are confident of clinching a trade deal before a July 9 deadline. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Friday that the US could wrap up its most important trade deals by Labor Day. The US and China signed an interim trade agreement on Friday that would reduce tariffs while the two sides work toward a formal deal. Trump administration officials have softened their stance toward the July 9 deadline they set for themselves to hammer out trade pacts. Beijing has backed up the plans for trade easing laid out by the US. Nike (NKE) could see a $1 billion tariff hit to profits this year. President Trump has said the US could sign a “very big” trade deal soon that would open up the Indian market to American businesses. President Trump said Thursday that the US and China have "signed" a trade deal, cementing months-long negotiations. The deal builds on meetings in Geneva between representatives of both nations and implements measures previously agreed upon. The US and China agreed to a 90-day reduction in tariffs while working toward a formal deal. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer met in London with Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng. The parties said they had reached an agreement. The announcement comes a deadline looms for the US to reimpose tariffs of up to 50% on several trading partners by July 9 unless the countries reach permanent agreements. Lutnick has hinted that deals are incoming with the largest trade partners.

title: FE Exclusive | Nirmala Sitharaman says ‘economic buoyancy can’t be overstated’ – Full Interview
content: In an exclusive interview with FE, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman talks about economic growth, manufacturing and reform while navigating global volatility and pushing for inclusive, ...
resumen:
In an exclusive interview with FE, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman discussed economic growth, manufacturing, and reform while navigating global volatility and pushing for inclusive, investment-driven development and simplified GST.

Sitharaman stated that she would like to have a trade agreement with the US. The negotiating team ensured that industry’s concerns were all taken on board before they sat at the table for talks. Agriculture and dairy have been among the very big red lines, where a high degree of caution has been exercised.

Sitharaman mentioned that India has only eight duties, inclusive of zero tariff. There have been drastic cuts in tariffs in the July (main) and February (interim) budgets. The effective tariff rates are lower than the limits announced in the gazette with Parliament approval, which is itself far below the WTO boundary.

Sitharaman stated that the US President has to go to Congress for reducing duties, a time-consuming process.

Sitharaman said that the trade negotiations should not get initiated by non-tariff concerns. Issues such as environment, gender, sustainability, carbon tax, government procurement, industrial relations, haven’t been strictly part of trade negotiations. On government procurement, a lot of carve-outs have to be made, to ensure purchases from MSMEs, start-ups etc.

Sitharaman said that globally, merchandise exports are actually declining, but the same agencies see India’s exports going up.

Sitharaman stated that labour-intensive units will be given support. Manufacturing, whether it is employment-intensive, or requires automation, policy support will be given.

Sitharaman said that from April, there have clearly been signs of the (positive consumer) sentiment playing out (thanks to the income tax reliefs). Sentiment is definitely turning in urban India.

Sitharaman said that there is a buoyancy in the economy, which cannot be overstated.

Sitharaman said that the various government departments concerned – those dealing with fertilisers, fossil fuels, components sourcing, critical minerals etc.– have lived up to their mandate during these times.

Sitharaman stated that if an economy is dynamic enough for people to make profit, and if the investment climate is such that exit is not difficult, it speaks volumes for it.

Sitharaman said that in the last six months, there is a clear sign that private investments and capacity expansion are happening.

Sitharaman said that the government of India empowers the citizen in various other ways too. When free food grain reaches a very large section of people, for instance, it’s getting added to the $3 per day, being below which is termed acute poverty, or to the $5 threshold for poverty.

Sitharaman said that the time has come for getting some consensus in the GST Council and coming up with a very simplified and easy-to-comply GST. The expectation is that the weighted average rate will come down.

Sitharaman said that on labour, the intent has been shown in the three labour codes that we brought in, and subsequently, states are also keenly taking it up. As regards logistics efficiency, which is very important for trade, a lot of activities are happening.

Sitharaman said that a major step was taken for energy efficiency in announcing this small, medium, small modular nuclear reactors. The reforms agenda also includes digitising land records. A lot of emphasis has been laid on 100 districts to enhance agricultural productivity under the Dhan Dhanya KrishiYojana.

Sitharaman said that the regional rural banks (RRBs) are doing well.

Sitharaman said that banks are not going to stop, they need to go to the market to raise funds. But CASA was a cheap capital available.

title: FE Exclusive | Nirmala Sitharaman says ‘economic buoyancy can’t be overstated; else, we wouldn’t…’
content: In an exclusive interview with FE, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman talks about economic growth, manufacturing and reform while navigating global volatility and pushing for inclusive, ...
resumen:
In an exclusive interview with FE, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman discussed economic growth, manufacturing, and reform while navigating global volatility and pushing for inclusive, investment-driven development and simplified GST.

Sitharaman stated that she would like to have a trade agreement with the US. The negotiating team ensured that industry’s concerns were all taken on board before they sat at the table for talks. Agriculture and dairy have been among the very big red lines, where a high degree of caution has been exercised.

Sitharaman mentioned that India has only eight duties, inclusive of zero tariff. There have been drastic cuts in tariffs in the July (main) and February (interim) budgets. Sitharaman stated that the trade negotiations should not get initiated by non-tariff concerns. Issues such as environment, gender, sustainability, carbon tax, government procurement, industrial relations, haven’t been strictly part of trade negotiations. Sitharaman said that globally, merchandise exports are actually declining, but the same agencies see India’s exports going up. The country still suffers from many taxes (at the state and local levels) that are not fully eliminated for exporting companies. As for the Centre’s taxes, we have (achieved zero-rating for exports), and because of the Integrated GST, we know where we stand on this, with no burden imposed on exporters.

Sitharaman stated that labour-intensive units will be given support. Manufacturing, whether it is employment-intensive, or requires automation, policy support will be given. A complete recast is happening even in labour-intensive industries, to the extent that traditional labels don’t hold.

Sitharaman said that from April, there have clearly been signs of the (positive consumer) sentiment playing out (thanks to the income tax reliefs). Sentiment is definitely turning in urban India.

Sitharaman said that there is a buoyancy in the economy, which cannot be overstated. GST receipts at over 7% of GDP seem to have crossed VAT/excise-era levels. The economy, in its multifarious indicators, is showing vibrancy.

Sitharaman stated that post-2020, absolute disruption has been the norm, and it seems to be the new normal. The various government departments concerned – those dealing with fertilisers, fossil fuels, components sourcing, critical minerals etc.– have lived up to their mandate during these times.

Sitharaman said that if an economy is dynamic enough for people to make profit, and if the investment climate is such that exit is not difficult, it speaks volumes for it. At least in the last six months, there is a clear sign that private investments and capacity expansion are happening.

Sitharaman said that it is important for us to understand multi-dimensional poverty and its measurements are not what the “international communism” stated earlier; it’s all taken a different form.

Sitharaman said that the time has come for getting some consensus in the GST Council and coming up with a very simplified and easy-to-comply GST. The expectation is that the weighted average rate will come down.

Sitharaman said that on labour, the intent has been shown in the three labour codes that we brought in, and subsequently, states are also keenly taking it up. As regards logistics efficiency, which is very important for trade, a lot of activities are happening. A major step was taken for energy efficiency in announcing this small, medium, small modular nuclear reactors. The reforms agenda also includes digitising land records. A lot of emphasis has been laid on 100 districts to enhance agricultural productivity under the Dhan Dhanya KrishiYojana. We are also getting banks to be better off. The regional rural banks (RRBs) are doing well.

Sitharaman said that banks are not going to stop, they need to go to the market to raise funds. But CASA was a cheap capital available. But given that we are in a downward cycle of the interest rates, how much lower interest can they give and why that should be an attraction for the customer are to be assessed.

title: Canada rescinds Digital Services Tax to restart U.S. trade talks
content: Ottawa announced it was rescinding a tax on technology firms generating revenue from Canadians just hours before it was to take effect in an effort to move forward trade negotiations with the United ...
resumen: On Sunday, Ottawa rescinded its Digital Services Tax. Ottawa announced late Sunday that it was rescinding a tax on technology firms generating revenue from Canadians just hours before it was to take effect, in an effort to move forward trade negotiations with the United States. Ottawa's Department of Finance announced in a statement that because they were scrapping the Digital Services Tax, Prime Minister Mark Carney and U.S. President Donald Trump have agreed to resume trade negotiations with the goal of signing a deal by July 21. The Digital Services Tax sought to ensure domestic and foreign companies profiting off Canadians online were paying taxes on that revenue. It levied a 3% tax on revenue earned from certain digital services that rely on the engagement data and content of Canadian users as well as certain sales of Canadian user data. Companies to be affected were online market place and advertising services as well as social media companies, including Google, Apple, Amazon and Meta. The tax was to take effect Monday, amid ongoing trade negotiations between Canada and the United States. Trump on Friday unilaterally called the talks off after being informed American technology companies would be hit with the 3% tax, which he described as "a direct and blatant attack on our Country." Trump said he will inform Ottawa within seven days of "the Tariff that they will be paying to do business with the United States of America.". Prime Minister Mark Carney's Liberal Party won a minority government in Parliament in late April.

title: Canada Drops Big Tech Tax Under Pressure, Resumes Trade Talks with US After Threats from Trump
content: “Today’s announcement will support a resumption of negotiations toward the July 21, 2025 ... tariffs to Canada and Mexico under anti-fentanyl provisions, although some goods remain exempt under the ...
resumen: Canada has rescinded its digital services tax to restart trade talks with Trump, avoiding a $2bn hit to US firms. Prime Minister Mark Carney announced late Sunday that trade talks between Ottawa and Washington are back on, just hours before the Canadian-imposed 3% levy on tech companies like Amazon, Meta, Google and Airbnb was set to take effect. The tax would have been retroactive, with US firms owing an estimated $2 billion in back payments by the end of June. Carney’s office said the decision was made “in anticipation” of progress toward a new trade agreement and came after a phone call with Trump on Sunday. “Today’s announcement will support a resumption of negotiations toward the July 21, 2025, timeline set out at this month’s G7 Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis,” Carney said. Just two days earlier, Trump had abruptly frozen all trade talks with Canada in response to the tax, calling it “a direct and blatant attack on our country.” On his Truth Social platform, the president said Canada had “refused to back down” an accusation that now appears to have been resolved behind closed doors. Canadian Finance Minister François-Philippe Champagne also confirmed talks with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, saying in a statement, “Rescinding the digital services tax will allow the negotiations of a new economic and security relationship with the United States to make vital progress.” The tax, which would have applied to digital revenue earned from Canadian users, had drawn sharp criticism from US officials and tech firms. Trump, now in his second term, has imposed steep tariffs on Canadian steel, aluminum, and automobiles, and threatened further action if a new trade agreement is not reached by July 21. His administration has also applied separate tariffs to Canada and Mexico under anti-fentanyl provisions, although some goods remain exempt under the USMCA agreement signed in 2020. During the G7 summit earlier this month, he even joked that Canada might someday become a US state.

title: Canada Drops Digital Services Tax, Resumes Trade Talks with U.S.
content: Today’s announcement will support a resumption of negotiations toward the July 21, 2025, timeline set out at this ... lobbyists viewed it as discriminatory under USMCA terms and countered with threats ...
resumen: Canada has rescinded its Digital Services Tax (DST). This clears the path to relaunch trade negotiations with the United States. The announcement was made by Prime Minister Mark Carney. The move was confirmed in a statement from Finance Minister François‑Philippe Champagne. The goal is to resume talks toward the July 21, 2025, timeline set out at this month’s G7 Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis. The announcement followed a phone call between Prime Minister Mark Carney and U.S. President Donald Trump, as well as a separate exchange involving Minister Champagne and U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent. Trump had abruptly terminated trade talks on Friday, labelling the DST a “direct and blatant attack” on American tech firms like Google, Amazon, and Meta. Canada was set to collect the first DST payment retroactive to 2022 by June 30—an estimated $2 billion upfront, with total revenues over five years projected at $7.2 billion. By scrapping the DST, Canada aims to resume talks with the goal of finalizing a new economic and security partnership by July 21, 2025. Minister Champagne emphasized the reversal was made in Canada’s best interest. The legislation to formally repeal the DST Act will be introduced shortly. The DST was part of the Trudeau government’s 2019 promise, passed into law in June 2024. It targeted large digital companies earning over $20 million annually from Canadian users.

title: How tariffs should and should not be used
content: Tariffs invite retaliations and retaliations lead to all-out trade wars. If a single word can sum up world economic activity in the first five months of ...
resumen:
Tariffs invite retaliations and retaliations lead to all-out trade wars.

The world’s governments and business communities have been preoccupied with the American President’s policy of imposing ‘reciprocal tariffs’ on all imports into the U.S. since Jan. 20, when Donald Trump began his second presidency.

The tariffs ranged from 10 percent – the general figure – all the way to 145 percent on Chinese exports to the U.S.

The tariff on Philippine exports has been set at 17 percent.

Trump has told the American people that his tariff campaign would accomplish two things: (1) stop the “ripping off” of America by other countries and (2) compel American companies to transfer their overseas manufacturing operations back to the U.S.

A tariff is an economic policy tool whose legitimate uses are trade protection and revenue generation.

A tariff can be used purely for revenue-generation purposes.

A tariff can be deployed not as a legitimate economic policy tool but as a geopolitical weapon for harassment, intimidation or coercion.

A tariff is an economic policy instrument intended to accomplish three principal objectives: encourage the transformation of an economy, regulate the flow of foreign goods into an economy and protect a country’s terms of trade.

Countries set their tariffs at low levels for goods that are necessary for production and consumption and at high levels for goods whose entry they wish to discourage.

Countries impose defensive countervailing tariffs on foreign goods that are produced in an unfair manner, e.g. through the enjoyment of subsidies from their governments.

A tariff always has price repercussions except in the very rare case where the importer absorbs the tariff entirely.

The consumer will always end up bearing at least a part of the tariff.

Imposition of a tariff is essentially a hostile act, and, like all hostile acts, must be undertaken only after the most careful evaluation of its broad economic implications.

The world has been in an undeclared trade war since Jan. 20, 2025, thanks entirely to the Trump administration’s tariff program.

title: Hang Seng Index News: Will Tariff Tensions Derail Bullish Momentum Toward 25,000?
content: Tariff tensions and weak China PMIs weigh on the Hang Seng Index as traders eye Fed rate cut bets and stimulus hopes.
resumen:
Key Points:

*   Hang Seng Index retreats as US-China tariff uncertainties and weak China PMIs weigh on EV and tech stocks.
*   BYD and Li Auto shares fall on EV oversupply concerns and reports of ‘zero mileage’ used car exports.
*   PMI data shows China’s manufacturing remains in contraction, with export orders down for 14 straight months.
*   On June 30, the Hang Seng Index dropped, with electric vehicle (EV) and tech stocks dragging the Index into negative territory.
*   Manufacturing sector PMI numbers from China weighed on sentiment.
*   Economic data, trade headlines, geopolitical risks, and stimulus speculation continue to influence risk sentiment.
*   These factors could dictate if the Hang Seng Index will break below 24,000 or target 25,000.
*   US equity markets extended gains on June 27, as US data supported a more dovish Fed rate path.
*   The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.52%.
*   The Hang Seng Index fell 0.52% to 24,157 in morning trading on June 30.
*   EV and tech stocks came under selling pressure on reports of the US and China retaining tariffs.
*   Mainland China markets had a positive start to the week.
*   The CSI 300 and Shanghai Composite Index posted morning gains of 0.01% and 0.18%, respectively.
*   The absence of details on the US-China trade deal and weak PMI data from the Mainland capped gains.
*   EV stocks faced heavy selling pressure amid reports of Chinese EV makers double-counting sales by exporting ‘zero mileage’ used cars.
*   Intense domestic competition and price pressures remained a headwind.
*   BYD (01211) and Li Auto (02015) dropped 0.64% and 2.26%, respectively.
*   The Hang Seng TECH Index edged 0.07% higher.
*   While Baidu (09888) climbed 0.36, Alibaba (09988) and JD.com fell 1.43% and 0.69%, respectively.
*   The US Core PCE Price Index rose 2.7% year-on-year in May, up from 2.6% in April.
*   Personal income declined 0.4% month-on-month in May after rising 0.7% in April, while personal spending dropped 0.1% (April: +0.2%).
*   The US economy contracted by more than previously expected (Q1: -0.5% vs. prelim -0.3%).
*   The NBS Manufacturing PMI rose from 49.5 in May to 49.7 in June, remaining below the critical 50 neutral level.
*   The Non-Manufacturing PMI rising from 50.3 to 50.5 in June.
*   The Manufacturing PMI numbers pressured HK-listed stocks, with external orders falling for 14 consecutive months.
*   On June 30, PMI numbers from China influenced market sentiment.
*   US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent clarified tariffs on China are 30%, with 20% on fentanyl, while levies on the US remained at 10%.
*   Corporate profits fell 9.1% in May.
*   On June 30, the Hang Seng Index held above its May-June congestion zone despite the morning pullback.
*   The Index also traded above its 50-day Exponential Moving Average (EMA), indicating a bullish bias.
*   Easing Middle East tensions and the removal of tariffs could drive the Index above the June high of 24,533.
*   A sustained move above 24,533 may pave the way to the March high of 24,874.
*   A drop below 24,000 could bring 23,500 and the 50-day EMA into play.
*   Resistance: 24,533, and then 24,874.
*   Support: 24,000, 23,500, then the 50-day EMA at 23,445.
*   Short-term Bias: Bullish but hinged on the Iran-Israel truce holding, US-China trade developments, and stimulus-related updates.
*   US tariffs and a lack of stimulus support from Beijing may weigh on sentiment, potentially dragging the Index below 24,000.
*   Progress toward dropping tariffs could boost sentiment, driving the Index toward the March high of 24,874.

title: Trump says he’s not planning to extend a pause on global tariffs
content: President Donald Trump says he is not planning to extend a 90-day pause on tariffs on most nations beyond July 9, when the negotiating period he set would expire, and his administration will notify ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump says he is not planning to extend a 90-day pause on tariffs on most nations beyond July 9, when the negotiating period he set would expire, and his administration will notify countries that the trade penalties will take effect unless there are deals with the United States.

Letters will start going out “pretty soon” before the approaching deadline, he said.

Trump told Fox News Channel’s “Sunday Morning Futures” during a wide-ranging interview taped Friday and broadcast Sunday.

Trump had played down the deadline at a White House news conference Friday by noting how difficult it would be to work out separate deals with each nation. The administration had set a goal of reaching 90 trade deals in 90 days.

Negotiations continue, but “there’s 200 countries, you can’t talk to all of them,” he said in the interview.

A group of wealthy investors will make an offer to buy TikTok, Trump said, hinting at a deal that could safeguard the future of the popular social media platform, which is owned by China’s ByteDance.

Trump said he thinks he’ll need China approval, and he thinks President Xi (Jinping) will probably do it.

Trump did not offer any details about the investors, calling them “a group of very wealthy people.”

Trump said he would tell specifics in about two weeks.

Earlier this month, Trump signed an executive order to keep TikTok running in the U.S. for 90 more days to give his administration more time to broker a deal to bring the social media platform under American ownership.

U.S. strikes on Iran “obliterated” its nuclear facilities, Trump insisted, and he said whoever leaked a preliminary intelligence assessment suggesting Tehran’s nuclear program had been set back only a few months should be prosecuted.

Trump said Iran was “weeks away” from achieving a nuclear weapon before he ordered the strikes.

Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Sunday on X that Trump “exaggerated to cover up and conceal the truth.”

Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations, Amir Saeid Iravani, told CBS’ “Face the Nation” that his country’s nuclear program is peaceful and that uranium “enrichment is our right, and an inalienable right and we want to implement this right” under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

Rafael Grossi, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said on CBS that “it is clear that there has been severe damage, but it’s not total damage.”

Grossi also said the U.N. nuclear watchdog has faced pressure to report that Iran had a nuclear weapon or was close to one, but “we simply didn’t because this was not what we were seeing.”

Of the leak of the intelligence assessment, Trump said anyone found to be responsible should be prosecuted. Journalists who received it should be asked who their source was, he said. His press secretary said Thursday that the administration is investigating the matter.

Trump offered a more nuanced view when it comes to farm and hotel workers.

Trump said his administration is working on “some kind of a temporary pass” that could give farmers and hotel owners control over immigration raids at their facilities.

Earlier this month, Trump had called for a pause on immigration raids disrupting the farming, hotel and restaurant industries, but a top Homeland Security official followed up with a seemingly contradictory statement. Tricia McLaughlin said there would be “no safe spaces for industries who harbor violent criminals or purposely try to undermine” immigration enforcement efforts.

Trump praised a recent trade deal with Beijing over rare earth exports from China and said establishing a fairer relationship will require significant tariffs.

Trump said he would be open to removing sanctions on Iranian oil shipments to China if Iran can show “they can be peaceful and if they can show us they’re not going to do any more harm.”

When Fox News Channel host Maria Bartiromo noted that China has tried to hack U.S. systems and steal intellectual property, Trump replied, “You don’t think we do that to them?”.

The tax charges retroactively from January 2022. U.S. companies would have faced up to $2.3 billion worth of annual losses, per the Computer & Communications Industry Association Research Center. title: World economy will slow sharply despite US-China tariff truce: Fitch
content: World economy still faces a sharp slowdown induced by the most severe trade war since the 1930s, said Fitch in its June 2025 GEO ...
resumen:
Fitch stated in its June 2025 GEO that the world economy still faces a sharp slowdown induced by the most severe trade war since the 1930s.

Fitch forecasts world GDP growth at 2.2% in 2025, an upward revision of 0.3pp since the April GEO. They also raised their forecasts for growth in 2026 to 2.2% from 2.0%. These rates are well below the 2.9% recorded in 2024 and the longer-term average of 2.7%.

Fitch has raised the US growth outlook for 2025 to 1.5% from 1.2%.

China’s 2025 growth forecast has also been raised to 4.2% from 3.9%.

They revised up eurozone growth to 0.8% from 0.6%.

The US Effective Tariff Rate (ETR) is 14.2%. The base case assumes it will rise slightly further in the coming months, approaching the 18% rate assumed in the March GEO. This is well below the 27% rate assumed in the April GEO.

Fitch's latest GDP forecasts remain weaker than in the March GEO.

The tariffs have reduced US business and consumer confidence and prompted a spike in US imports in 1Q25.

In China, fiscal easing is the key policy lever to offset the US tariff shock.

For Germany, US tariff hikes – including on autos – are yet another adverse external shock.

The Federal Reserve is likely to be cautious about cutting rates as US growth slows, and they still expect only a single rate cut this year in 4Q25.

Fitch Ratings has raised its 2025 annual average oil price assumption by $5 to $70 a barrel.

The ECB expects a further cut in rates to a below-neutral 1.75% in September.

title: Geopolitical Tensions Nudge Oil Outlook Higher, but Demand Concerns Persist: Reuters Poll
content: A survey of 40 economists and analysts in June forecast Brent crude will average $67.86 per barrel in 2025, up from May's $66.98 forecast, while U.S. crude is seen at $64.51, above last month's $63.35 ...
resumen:
A Reuters poll of 40 economists and analysts in June forecast Brent crude will average $67.86 per barrel in 2025, up from May's $66.98 forecast, while U.S. crude is seen at $64.51, above last month's $63.35 estimate. Prices have averaged roughly $70.80 and $67.50 so far this year respectively, as per LSEG data.

The Iran-Israel conflict and the U.S. decision to intervene have led to sharp swings in oil prices this month, with Brent prices touching $81.40 before falling to settle at $67.14 after the ceasefire.

Analysts expect global oil demand to grow by an average of over 730,000 bpd in 2025, compared to 775,000 bpd in last month's poll.

OPEC+ in May agreed to another increase of 411,000 barrels per day of oil for July, bringing the total increases made or announced since April to 1.37 million bpd.

title: Gold falls to one-month low as trade optimism spurs risk appetite
content: BENGALURU] Gold prices fell to their lowest in more than a month on Monday (Jun 30) as easing trade tensions between the US and China dampened safe-haven demand and prompted investors to pivot towards ...
resumen:
Gold prices fell to their lowest in more than a month on Monday (Jun 30) as easing trade tensions between the US and China dampened safe-haven demand and prompted investors to pivot towards riskier assets.

Spot gold was down 0.3 per cent at US$3,264.64 per ounce, as at 0055 GMT, after hitting its lowest level since May 29. US gold futures fell 0.4 per cent to US$3,275.30.

The United States and China have resolved issues surrounding shipments of rare earth minerals and magnets to the US, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Friday.

US President Donald Trump abruptly cut off trade talks with Canada on Friday over its tax targeting US technology firms, saying that it was a “blatant attack” and that he would set a new tariff rate on Canadian goods within the next week.

The ceasefire between Iran and Israel after a 12-day conflict also appeared to be holding, further reducing safe-haven demand.

Spot silver was down 0.4 per cent at US$35.84 per ounce, platinum firmed 0.4 per cent to US$1,344.63, while palladium fell 0.6 per cent to US$1,127.23.

title: Wall Street opens higher as trade thaw, tech surge power strong end to June
content: US stocks rose on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq looking to extend their record run as easing trade tensions and tech-led gains lifted sentiment. Canada’s digital tax rollback, upbeat tech moves, ...
resumen: On Monday, June 30, 2025, Wall Street opened higher. US stocks rose, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq looking to extend their record run. S&P 500 futures rose 0.4 percent, Nasdaq futures gained 0.54 percent, and Dow Jones Industrial Average futures climbed 0.51 percent in pre-market trading. Canada’s decision to withdraw its proposed digital services tax lifted sentiment for tech giants like Meta Platforms and Alphabet, which saw early gains of nearly 2 percent each, while Microsoft advanced 0.5 percent. The S&P 500 has climbed 4.49 percent this month, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq has surged 6.1 percent, and the Dow has added 3.7 percent. The S&P 500’s breakout from a pennant pattern last week could push the index toward 6,100 or even 6,575, with key support levels at 5,770 and 5,650. Euro Stoxx 50 futures rose 0.43 percent in pre-market trading. Germany’s DAX rose 2.92 percent, France’s CAC 40 advanced 1.34 percent, and Italy’s FTSE MIB climbed 1.3 percent last week. Moderna jumped 2% after reporting positive late-stage results for its standalone flu vaccine, while Hewlett Packard Enterprise soared 14% following a DOJ settlement clearing its $14 billion acquisition of Juniper Networks. Meta Platforms gained attention after hiring four senior AI researchers for its Superintelligence group. Bloom Energy also stood out, rallying 12.8% in pre-market trading. FedEx shares faced pressure, down 5%. Gold futures edged up to $3,300.20, while West Texas Intermediate crude slipped slightly to just below $75. Bitcoin traded at $107,000. The 10-year Treasury note yield held steady at 4.47 percent.

title: A multipolar world, a vulnerable Sri Lanka
content: As the global order undergoes sweeping shifts, with geopolitics, trade tensions, and macroeconomic uncertainty converging, small economies such as Sri Lanka find themselves at a critical crossroads. .
resumen:
The article discusses the challenges Sri Lanka faces in a shifting global order.

Prof. Razeen Sally, a senior economist, and Daily Mirror Business Editor Shabiya Ali Ahlam discussed the current state of geopolitics, the global economic trajectory, and the impact on Sri Lanka.

Prof. Sally describes the current state of geopolitics as a structural shift from relative order and stability to increasing disorder, with a reduced American willingness and capacity to provide global public goods. He notes the rise of China and the weakness of other players like the EU and the UK, leading to a multipolar world.

He predicts a shift from predictability to unpredictability, volatility, and a loss of confidence in the global economy. The IMF predicts global growth will fall to about 2.3 percent this year, possibly rising to 2.5 percent next year and the year after, which is significantly lower than the pre-pandemic average. Developing countries are expected to be more affected.

The article also discusses the emergence of economic nationalism and mercantilism, with protectionism becoming the norm. Prof. Sally suggests that countries should liberalize as much as possible.

He foresees that external shocks, such as trade wars or a surge in oil prices, could tip Sri Lanka into another recession. He outlines three scenarios for Sri Lanka: drift, relapse, and sustainable growth. He believes that Sri Lanka is not doing enough to achieve sustainable growth. He notes that the government has the right intentions but lacks a clear understanding of the required structural reforms.

title: Economy Enters Second Half Facing Tight Fed, Trump Tariffs – But the Stock Market Is Roaring
content: The stock market is on a roll, but economists see a second-half slowdown. Thursday’s jobs report could provide some clues to where the economy is headed.
resumen:
The S&P 500 recorded a new high Friday, putting an end to a rapid recovery from the tariff-induced meltdown the stock market suffered in early April.

Economist Hugh Johnson wrote Sunday that performance suggests that we may be at the beginning of a new stock market-economic-interest rate cycle similar to the beginnings we have seen for the 26 cycles since 1890.

Johnson also points out the headwinds of tariffs and the global trade war, increased budget deficits and limitations on immigration, which could inhibit growth in the labor market.

President Donald Trump said Friday he was ending all negotiations with Canada because the northern neighbor is putting into place a digital service tax on U.S. technology firms.

Canada late Sunday said it was scrapping the tax hours before it was set to take effect.

The government on Thursday sharply revised down its estimate of first-quarter growth Thursday, as a surge in imports ahead of Trump’s import tariffs and weaker consumer spending and a decrease in federal outlays led to a 0.5% contraction in the economy.

The report was worse than economists had forecast, which was a 0.2% dip as had been estimated earlier this year.

A measure of inflation followed closely by the Federal Reserve continued to show that prices are rising at an annual level higher than the central bank’s 2% annual target.

The same report also showed a slowing in consumer spending.

Mark Vitner, chief economist at Piedmont Crescent Capital, said that business investment and durable goods orders showed surprising strength, but underlying demand is softer than earlier thought and many key measures are flashing warning signals.

Vintner added that real consumer spending was flat in May, with a downward revision to April.

Real disposable income is running below 2% year-over-year, even as the savings rate edges higher.

The monthly jobs report from the Labor Department for June is expected to show 113,000 jobs were created compared to May’s 139,000 increase.

The report will be issued Thursday.

Tuesday will kick off a round of reports on the labor market with the government’s latest number on job openings for May, which are expected to continue to hover around 7.3 million.

The June monthly employment report from private payroll firm ADP is expected to show 90,000 jobs added, a rebound from the paltry 37,000 increase in May.

Trump has called Fed Chairman Jerome Powell a “loser” for keeping interest rates elevated.

Raymond James Chief Investment Officer Larry Adam said that growth is expected to slow to 1.4% in 2025 as businesses and consumers adjust to tariffs and hiring cools, but the Fed still has room to act – with the fed funds rate around 4.5%.

Adam expects two rate cuts by year end and two more in 2026, helping growth pick up to 1.5% next year.

title: A new era for financial regulators
content: In a policy move many years in the making, federal regulators are proposing to scale back a key capital requirement for the biggest banks.
resumen: Federal regulators are proposing to scale back a key capital requirement for the biggest banks. Their chief goals include greasing the skids of trading U.S. government debt. The proposal would make it cheaper for big banks to hold less risky assets. A Treasury official said that the way it was put together is a blueprint for the role the department plans to play in bank regulation going forward. Treasury acted as a “convener,” creating a new dynamic for collaboration and has now built up momentum for further regulatory reforms. The official said Treasury’s participation allowed for a broader range of considerations beyond the scope of agencies’ responsibilities, like tradeoffs between growth and the structure of the financial system. The SLR reforms were never intended to be a salve for the bond market all on their own. Darrell Duffie, a professor at Stanford University’s Graduate School of Business, said they could make a difference in a crisis, when functioning in U.S. debt markets is most important. The FDIC holds a board meeting to vote on the SLR proposal at 10 a.m.

title: México tendrá crecimiento económico de 0.3 %, el menor de Latinoamérica, por políticas de EU: Instituto de Finanzas
content: El Instituto de Finanzas Internacionales (IIF, por sus siglas en inglés) advirtió que México podría tener un retorno de bajo crecimiento y vuelva a niveles de cuando se encontraba en confinamiento por ...
resumen: El Instituto de Finanzas Internacionales (IIF) advirtió que México podría tener un retorno de bajo crecimiento y vuelva a niveles de cuando se encontraba en confinamiento por la pandemia por Covid–19. El IIF aseguró que México tendrá un menor crecimiento económico en América Latina para este 2025, pues las políticas implementadas del presidente de EU, Donald Trump, como los aranceles, remesas, redadas migratorias y la renegociación del T-MEC, además de que el gobierno instaló la reforma judicial y “son un obstáculo a enfrentar”. El país enfrenta obstáculos estructurales como la reorganización de cadenas de suministro, el limitado margen para el estímulo político. El organismo internacional pronosticó que la inversión extranjera disminuirá por los cambios que se han realizado en el gobierno de EU. El organismo dijo que se ejercerá una presión sobre cuentas equilibradas en el sector del acero y aluminios, pues es una “alta exposición” por parte del gobierno estadounidense. La reforma judicial “puede considerarse como violaciones al T-MEC y alimentar la intención de Estados Unidos de realizar enmiendas sustanciales”. El Banco de México (Banxico) recortó sus pronósticos de crecimiento para la economía mexicana al estimar un crecimiento de 0.1% para 2025 y de 0.9% en 2026. El intervalo para la variación del PIB para ese año se modifica a uno de entre 0.1 y 1.7%. El informe trimestral de enero a marzo detalla que se prevé que la actividad económica nacional presente atonía en el horizonte de pronóstico. Se suma los significativos retos para la economía global del cambio de política comercial en Estados Unidos. Existe incertidumbre sobre los posibles efectos que esto pueda tener sobre la demanda externa en México. El informe trimestral de Banxico, el complejo contexto internacional ha añadido una elevada incertidumbre a las previsiones presentadas para la actividad productiva nacional. Persiste incertidumbre respecto de las medidas arancelarias que Estados Unidos decida implementar de manera definitiva. Otros de los riesgos son que el crecimiento de la economía de Estados Unidos sea menor a lo esperado, que haya un escalamiento de diversos conflictos geopolíticos en distintas regiones del mundo, lo que tendría repercusiones en la economía global y el comercio internacional y que ocurran fenómenos meteorológicos como temperaturas extremas, ciclones o sequías que impacten adversamente la actividad económica.

title: El pulso de Sánchez por el gasto en Defensa lleva a España a su mayor crisis con EEUU desde la Guerra de Cuba
content: El presidente español firma el 5% en defensa en la OTAN y lo rechaza de palabra tras la cumbre: Trump advierte de que prepara represalias comerciales contra España. Más información: Trump amenaza a Es ...
resumen:
El pulso de Sánchez por el gasto en Defensa lleva a España a su mayor crisis con EEUU desde la Guerra de Cuba.

El presidente español firma el 5% en defensa en la OTAN y lo rechaza de palabra tras la cumbre: Trump advierte de que prepara represalias comerciales contra España.

Donald Trump amenaza a España por negarse a gastar el 5% en defensa: "Es terrible. Les voy a hacer pagar el doble".

La bronca de Donald Trump a España, en su intervención final al acabar la cumbre de la OTAN, abre a España su mayor crisis diplomática con Estados Unidos desde la Guerra de Cuba de 1898.

El motivo del enfrentamiento tiene que ver con el gasto militar.

Desde Washington hacia Madrid hubo indiferencia hasta que Eisenhower y Franco encontraron cómo entenderse.

José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero provocó un largo episodio de "desconfianza".

Primero, no levantarse al paso de la bandera estadounidense en el desfile del 12-O de 2003.

Luego por llegar a presidente y exhibir, como primera decisión, la retirada unilateral "y sin aviso" de las tropas españolas de Irak.

El pulso de Sánchez en la cumbre de la OTAN visualizó su aislamiento en la foto de familia.

La negativa pública de Sánchez a asumir lo que, aun así, firmó -el 5% del PIB para gasto en Defensa- fue la estrella del cierre de Mark Rutte y otros líderes en la capital neerlandesa.

Fuentes diplomáticas consultadas lo resumen sin ambages: "El coste político y el desgaste diplomático de España en esta Cumbre es aterrador. Una hemorragia de credibilidad y confianza perdidas respecto a nuestros aliados. Un desastre".

Otra fuente cercana a la Alianza señala que "el contraste con otros países europeos, como Alemania, es abrumador. Allí, la coalición de Gobierno mantiene una postura sólida y predecible, incluso en momentos de máxima presión".

La declaración final de la cumbre es clara: "Unidos frente a las profundas amenazas y desafíos a la seguridad, en particular la amenaza a largo plazo que plantea Rusia a la seguridad euroatlántica y la persistente amenaza del terrorismo, los Aliados se comprometen a invertir anualmente el 5% del PIB…".

Moncloa asegura que la fórmula "los aliados se comprometen" no tiene por qué incluir a todos, sino sólo a los que así lo asumen.

El presidente fue claro en su rueda de prensa: "Nuestros militares dicen que cumpliremos con los objetivos de capacidad con el 2,1%... así que, como dijimos antes de la cumbre, no asumimos el 5%".

Sánchez sentenció que "el 2,1% es una inversión suficiente, realista y compatible con nuestro modelo social", en la rueda de prensa tras la cumbre.

Trump amenazó con "represalias comerciales" si España no cumple con el compromiso de gasto militar.

"Es el único país que rechaza pagar, es ir un poco de gorra, así que van a pagar a través del comercio. Les vamos a hacer pagar el doble", advirtió el mandatario estadounidense.

La amenaza se puede traducir no sólo en aranceles, sino en desinversiones, sanciones y sobreprecios a productos clave, como el gas licuado.

Desde la guerra en la que Estados Unidos le arrebató Cuba a España en 1898, las relaciones entre España y Estados Unidos estuvieron medio siglo marcadas por ciclos entre el distanciamiento y la indiferencia.

La derrota española supuso la pérdida de los últimos territorios coloniales y un trauma nacional que condicionó durante décadas la actitud de España hacia la gran potencia americana.

Tras la contienda, Washington y Madrid mantuvieron relaciones diplomáticas frías.

El punto de inflexión llegó durante la Guerra Fría.

La alianza estratégica entre la España de Francisco Franco y los Estados Unidos de Dwight Eisenhower, sellada con los acuerdos de bases militares de 1953, permitió la instalación de tropas estadounidenses en suelo español.

El pacto dio estabilidad al régimen franquista.

Con la llegada de la democracia se generó una percepción de dependencia y sumisión que se acentuó con el viraje de Felipe González desde el NO a la OTAN al referéndum que convocó para defender la permanencia en la Alianza.

El acercamiento de José María Aznar a George W. Bush, con escenas como la del presidente español con los pies sobre la mesa en una cumbre del G-7 y la foto de las Azores.

El episodio de Zapatero sentado ante la bandera de EEUU en el desfile militar del 12 de octubre de 2003, abrió una profunda herida diplomática que nunca cerró del todo... y que ahora se reabre en canal con la actitud de Sánchez en la OTAN.

Fuentes diplomáticas consultadas tras la cumbre de La Haya comparan ambos episodios.

"Es como aquella escena, o peor en realidad. Es todo un delirio", apunta un exembajador.

"La diferencia es que ahora el presidente estadounidense es Trump", conocido por su estilo agresivo.

El Partido Popular de Alberto Núñez Feijóo ve cómo el cumplimiento del 5% en Defensa le puede tocar cumplirlo cuando le toque gobernar.

"Pedro Sánchez se ha comprometido con la filosofía de rearme de la OTAN, pero trata de calmar a sus socios diciendo que ha engañado a la Alianza y que sólo pagará el 2,1%", denuncia el PP.

"La farsa terminó, se ha firmado el 5%", tuiteaba Feijóo.

"Unidos los aliados se comprometen, significa todos los aliados. De lo contrario, no estarían unidos", señalan fuentes del Partido Popular.

El desgaste diplomático de España en esta cumbre es evidente para un experto atlantista: "España se ha convertido en una molestia. Ensombrecerá su reputación y prestigio durante bastante tiempo. Uno se pregunta qué justifica esta pantomima y qué ganará España con este espectáculo y esta burla. Es una verdadera lástima".

La credibilidad de España como "aliado fiable" está "en entredicho".

En el entorno de Sánchez se respiraba satisfacción, por el "objetivo conseguido".

En Moncloa no se quería el enfrentamiento directo, sino simplemente marcar perfil.

Otros diplomáticos y especialistas admiten que "Trump no estuvo especialmente guerrero en su conferencia de prensa" o que "el presidente español sigue siendo respetado" por su arrojo.

El presidente español se justificó, apelando a la soberanía nacional y al Estado del bienestar.

La OTAN avisa a Sánchez de que tendrá que "encontrar dinero" para Defensa y niega una "excepción" para España.

"Si hubiéramos aceptado el 5%, España tendría que destinar más de 300.000 millones de euros extra a defensa hasta 2035. ¿De dónde

title: A relentless Trump battles a steadfast Powell on rate cuts. Who’s right?
content: President Trump certainly thinks so. He’s pounding the table for immediate rate cuts, and two of the central bank’s five governors agree. In a rare public break, they said it would make sense to start ...
resumen:
The Federal Reserve waited too long to raise interest rates when prices took off in 2021. Now, with inflation nearly back in the central bank’s comfort zone, are policy makers dragging their feet again — this time on the way down?

President Trump is pounding the table for immediate rate cuts, and two of the central bank’s five governors agree. They said it would make sense to start reducing rates as soon as their next meeting in July, not months down the road as Fed chair Jerome Powell has suggested.

The president is considering nominating a successor much earlier than usual who could serve as a kind of shadow chair before Powell’s tenure ends in May.

The Fed directly controls short-term rates, which influence borrowing costs on mortgages, credit cards, and business loans.

Vice President JD Vance said Tuesday on X: “I’d love to hear an argument for why Powell cut rates 50 points right before an election but can’t do it now with inflation lower.”

The Fed voted last week to leave its benchmark lending rate unchanged at about 4.3 percent. The short-term federal funds rate hasn’t changed since December, following a full percentage point decline in 2024.

Officials hit the pause button after inflation ticked modestly higher last winter. More recently, inflation has been cooling, but the Fed is focused on what consumer prices will do when the impact of Trump’s tariffs becomes clear.

The big unknown: Will import taxes — now the steepest since the 1930s — lead to a one-time boost to inflation that the Fed could ignore? Or will they trigger a spiral of rapidly rising prices that would force policy makers to keep rates elevated.

Michelle Bowman, vice chair for supervision of the Federal Reserve: "I would support lowering the policy rate as soon as our next meeting."

The Fed’s preferred price gauge — the personal consumption expenditures index excluding food and energy — fell to an annualized 2.1 percent in April from 2.6 percent at the end of last year. Its target is 2 percent.

Michelle Bowman, the Fed’s vice chair for supervision and a Trump appointee, said on Wednesday: “Should inflation pressures remain contained, I would support lowering the policy rate as soon as our next meeting in order to bring it closer to its neutral setting and to sustain a healthy labor market.”

Fed Governor Christopher Waller, another Trump appointee, also said he expected tariffs would boost inflation only temporarily. But Waller dismissed a key argument Trump has voiced for immediately lowering rates: reducing interest payments on the national debt.

Waller said: “Our mandate from Congress tells us to worry about unemployment and price stability. It does not tell us to provide cheap financing to the US government.”

Gregory Daco, chief economist at EY-Parthenon, wrote Wednesday on LinkedIn: “Many firms, anticipating tariff hikes, accelerated shipments in February and March. This created a sizable inventory buffer, effectively delaying the moment when higher-cost goods reach store shelves.”

Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics: “I think the Fed should be allowed to do its job. If it cuts rates too soon, before it is clear that inflation is not a problem, it will be counterproductive. Mortgage rates and other borrowing costs will go up, and not down.”

title: 5 Insightful Analyst Questions From Teleflex’s Q1 Earnings Call
content: Teleflex’s first quarter results for 2025 prompted a negative market reaction, as revenues declined year over year and the company acknowledged persistent headwinds across multiple business segments.
resumen:
Teleflex's (TFX) first quarter results for 2025 prompted a negative market reaction, as revenues declined year over year and the company acknowledged persistent headwinds across multiple business segments. Management attributed the performance to continued challenges in its Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) business—driven by lost contracts and customer inventory management—alongside softness in UroLift and ongoing volume-based procurement pressures in China. CEO Liam Kelly noted, “The quarter evolved largely as expected,” but also cited the impact of macroeconomic factors and unfavorable product mix on margins.

Teleflex (TFX) Q1 CY2025 Highlights:
Revenue: $700.7 million vs analyst estimates of $699 million (5% year-on-year decline, in line).
Adjusted EPS: $2.91 vs analyst estimates of $2.88 (0.9% beat).
Adjusted EBITDA: $200 million vs analyst estimates of $189.4 million (28.5% margin, 5.6% beat).
Adjusted EPS guidance for the full year is $13.40 at the midpoint, missing analyst estimates by 4.9%.
Operating Margin: 17.9%, up from -0.6% in the same quarter last year.
Constant Currency Revenue fell 3.8% year on year (3.8% in the same quarter last year).
Market Capitalization: $5.27 billion.

Our Top 5 Analyst Questions Teleflex’s Q1 Earnings Call:
Patrick Wood (Morgan Stanley) asked whether OEM order improvement reflected supply chain shifts; CEO Liam Kelly responded that demand pickup was mostly base demand, not yet onshoring, but expected sequential improvement.
Michael Sarcone (Jefferies) pressed for details on tariff mitigation timing and EPS impact; CFO John Deren detailed ongoing supply chain, USMCA, and pricing strategies but cautioned against providing specific EPS offsets at this stage.
Jayson Bedford (Raymond James) questioned whether NewCo could be sold in parts or only as a whole; Kelly stated all options remain open, guided by maximizing shareholder value, and the process is running in parallel to a spin.
Craig Bijou (Bank of America) asked about Interventional Urology performance and UroLift’s outlook; Kelly said Palette continues to grow strongly, while UroLift remains pressured in the U.S. but is gaining traction in APAC.
Richard Newitter (Truist Securities) inquired about confidence in China’s recovery and potential product tariff exemptions; Kelly explained that the worst of China’s volume-based procurement impacts are likely past and expressed hope for medical device exemptions from tariffs.

Catalysts in Upcoming Quarters:
Analysts will closely monitor (1) the pace and effectiveness of tariff mitigation initiatives, including supply chain adjustments and pricing actions, (2) progress on the proposed separation and potential sale of NewCo assets, and (3) integration milestones for the BIOTRONIK Vascular Intervention acquisition. Additional focus will be on the recovery trajectories for OEM and China segments and the commercial traction of new products.
Teleflex currently trades at $119.15, down from $136.94 just before the earnings.

title: Democracy shouldn’t be used as an ideological weapon
content: The democracy-vs-autocracy framing has widened the divide between democratic countries — “us” — and Russia and its allies — “them.” ...
resumen: Democracy shouldn’t be used as an ideological weapon. Ukraine, Gaza and the Iraq War reveal the perils of prioritizing defense over values. The United Nations Security Council holds a vote during a meeting on the third anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine at the bodies headquarters in New York on Feb. 24. By Maiko Ichihara. Contributing Writer. Jun 26, 2025. Populism is threatening democracy around the world. However, authoritarian domestic actors are not the only danger to this political system: Ironically, discourse emphasizing democracy in international politics has also served to distract attention from its essence. When Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine began three years ago, Western leaders framed the war in Ukraine as a battle not only in defense of sovereignty, one of the most widely shared norms in international politics, but democracy as well. Yet this narrative was merely focused on the national defense of a democratic state. It had the paradoxical effect of downplaying the institutions and values that define democracy, replacing them with an ideology centered on conflict between states.

title: Mexico close to striking a deal on US steel tariffs, Bloomberg reports
content: Bloomberg reports that the "developing framework" would alleviate crushing duties on some of the Mexican steel imports that U.S. automakers need.
resumen: Mexico could get a reprieve from the United States’ 50% tariffs on steel imports, but only on exports up to a certain limit, according to the Bloomberg news agency. The United States imposed 25% tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports in March, and doubled the rate to 50% this month. Trade negotiations between the United States and Mexico are “homing in on a possible quota system to reduce tariffs on a certain volume of steel imports.” The news agency said that “the developing framework” would “alleviate crushing duties for some of the Mexican steel imports that U.S. automakers and other industries have described as essential.” A “tariff-free steel quota” could be established based on Mexico’s export volumes between 2015 and 2017. A quota based on 2015-2017 volumes would equate to about 2.79 million metric tonnes of steel per year, according to data from the United States Department of Commerce. Steel imports from Mexico “under any threshold specified under the deal would avoid the 50% tariff but are still expected to be hit with a 10% baseline charge.” Amounts above it would be subjected to the full [50%] duty. A “tariff-free” or “tariff-reduced” quota of 2.79 million tonnes of steel per year would represent about 88% of Mexico’s steel exports to the United States last year, which totaled  3.19 million metric tonnes. Bloomberg did not report on any negotiations between the United States and Mexico related to the 50% tariff on aluminum. Mexico is the third-largest exporter of steel to the United States, but it imports more of that metal, and aluminum, from the U.S. than it sends to its northern neighbor. Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard has traveled to Washington, D.C. on several occasions to negotiate exemptions, or at least reductions, of U.S. tariffs on steel, aluminum and vehicles made in Mexico. He is aiming to negotiate exemptions, or at least reductions, of U.S. tariffs on steel, aluminum and vehicles made in Mexico. On June 4 — the date the 50% tariff on steel and aluminum exports to the U.S. took effect — President Claudia Sheinbaum said: “In the case of Mexico, firstly, it’s unjust … because as we have said several times, Mexico imports more [from the United States] than it exports in steel and aluminum. Formally, a tariff is imposed when there is a deficit. … Secondly, from our perspective, it has no legal basis because there is a trade agreement.” The trade agreement she was referring to is the USMCA. Sheinbaum said last Wednesday that in a telephone call with U.S. President Donald Trump she proposed a separate “general agreement” between Mexico and the United States covering security, migration and trade. Sheinbaum said last Thursday that the Mexican government’s “objective” was for the agreement to be signed “very soon.”

title: Multilateralism will need to evolve to become more ‘flexible’, says Singapore PM Wong at WEF event
content: In response to the world's common threats, PM Wong said Singapore has sought to make multilateralism “more resilient, more inclusive, and better suited to the realities of our time." ...
resumen:
Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said multilateralism will need to evolve to become more ‘flexible’ in a dialogue at a World Economic Forum (WEF) event in Tianjin, China, on June 25, 2025.

Singapore is proposing a workaround of getting like-minded countries to cooperate on specific issues, while leaving the door open for others to join in the future.

PM Wong said, “This is what we call a flexible multilateralism.”

He added that the efforts should be open and inclusive.

He urged countries to update, evolve and improve the multilateral system.

The US has imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on Singapore.

PM Wong said, “For small countries like Singapore, we are worried because we have limited options, we have limited bargaining power, and we risk being marginalised.”

In response, Singapore has sought to make multilateralism “more resilient, more inclusive, and better suited to the realities of our time”.

Singapore, together with Japan and Australia, had pushed for a joint initiative about e-commerce at the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

After five years of negotiations, more than 70 countries have joined this initiative.

PM Wong told the moderator, WEF president Borge Brende, “The efforts may seem small and incremental, but if like-minded countries everywhere were to do our part, then collectively, I think we can make a difference.”

PM Wong was speaking at the Annual Meeting of the New Champions, a WEF event that attracted more than 1,700 global leaders.

Mr Brende asked PM Wong a question about how Singapore balances between its “special friends” – the US and China.

PM Wong said Singapore’s starting point is to look at how it advances its own national interest.

He said Singapore engages with not just America and China, but also other major powers.

title: Multilateralism can evolve to be more ‘flexible’, says PM Wong at WEF event
content: This means having like-minded nations cooperate on specific issues while leaving the door open for others to join. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said in a dialogue at a World Economic Forum (WEF) event in Tianjin, China, on June 25 that multilateralism can evolve to be more ‘flexible’. He said that Singapore is proposing a workaround of getting like-minded countries to cooperate on specific issues, while leaving the door open for others to join in the future. He called this "flexible multilateralism". He said that the efforts should be open and inclusive. He urged countries to update, evolve and improve the multilateral system, rather than abandon it altogether. The US has imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on Singapore. PM Wong said that for small countries like Singapore, they are worried because they have limited options, limited bargaining power, and risk being marginalised. He said bigger countries will also find it hard to deal with and operate in the new environment because it will be harder for the world to address common threats, such as pandemics, climate change or financial shocks. Singapore, together with Japan and Australia, had pushed for a joint initiative about e-commerce at the World Trade Organisation (WTO). More than 70 countries have joined this initiative. PM Wong told the moderator, WEF president Borge Brende, that if like-minded countries everywhere were to do their part, then collectively, they can make a difference. PM Wong said that trade will still exist, but with changing patterns. Other drivers for global growth are technology and the move towards sustainability. PM Wong was speaking at the Annual Meeting of the New Champions, a WEF event more commonly known as Summer Davos, that attracted more than 1,700 global leaders from businesses, government, civil society and academia. Mr. Brende asked PM Wong how Singapore balances between its “special friends” – the US and China. PM Wong said that Singapore’s starting point is to look at how it advances its own national interest. He said Singapore engages with not just America and China, but also other major powers. Asked by Mr Brende how Singapore navigates the fragmented geopolitical landscape and avoids ending up between a rock and a hard place, PM Wong said: “If we end up in a hard place, it’s not just us. Many other countries will also end up in a hard place, and I think the consequence of that will be disastrous for the world.
