title: “Trump hace la política de un promotor del Bronx que vende pisos”
content: José Manuel García-Margallo reflexiona sobre las decisiones de Trump en materia de comercio, defensa y multilateralismo.
resumen:
José Manuel García-Margallo, analista y observador de la presidencia de Donald Trump, considera que Trump aplica la política de un promotor del Bronx que vende pisos, comenzando con posiciones máximas para retroceder en la negociación.

García-Margallo menciona que Trump anuncia aranceles de gran magnitud para luego retroceder y que se podría llegar a un acuerdo con China.

García-Margallo cree que Estados Unidos tiene una crisis de valores y un relativismo moral, lo que explica su política contra la cultura "woke".

En política internacional, Trump considera que EE. UU. está en declive, citando el déficit comercial, fiscal y la deuda pública.

Trump no quiere intervenir en asuntos que no impliquen sus intereses, como en el caso de Ucrania.

García-Margallo señala que Trump se ha encontrado con la realidad, como la devaluación del dólar y el aumento de la desconfianza, lo que lo llevó a suspender aranceles.

García-Margallo pronostica un nuevo orden mundial con la reconstrucción de imperios: EE. UU., Rusia y China.

García-Margallo cree que el partido republicano es "trumpista puro" y que Trump tiene un poder mayor que en su primer mandato.

García-Margallo cree que Trump presionará para que se acepte un acuerdo sobre Ucrania, con Rusia quedándose con parte del territorio.

García-Margallo considera que la UE debe reaccionar ante esta situación para no ser irrelevante.

García-Margallo menciona que la división ya no es entre derechas e izquierdas, sino entre democracias liberales e iliberales.

García-Margallo señala que la UE está perdiendo la carrera tecnológica y que no se han creado megaempresas en la UE en los últimos 50 años.

García-Margallo dice que en Europa hay dos clases de países, los pequeños y los que no saben que lo son, y que en 20 años no habrá ninguna economía europea entre las ocho más grandes del mundo.

García-Margallo cree que la UE debe actuar unida en política comercial.

García-Margallo menciona que Trump quiere que Panamá baje las tarifas a los barcos americanos, reducir la influencia china y aumentar la presencia militar americana en Groenlandia.

García-Margallo considera que las relaciones de España con Estados Unidos no pueden ser peores.

title: Media Matters sues FTC, says agency is retaliating on behalf of Elon Musk
content: The FTC is led by Chairman Andrew Ferguson, who has argued that advertiser boycotts may violate antitrust law and pose "a pretty serious risk to the free exchange of ideas." The FTC currently has only ...
resumen: Media Matters for America sued the Federal Trade Commission, alleging that the FTC's ongoing investigation into the group "has violated Media Matters' First Amendment rights by retaliating against the organization for its reporting on Elon Musk and X.". The investigation is the latest effort by Elon Musk and his allies in the Trump administration to retaliate against Media Matters for its reporting on X, the social media site Musk controls. The group said it has suffered financially because of "the cascade of litigation launched by Musk and his allies.". The FTC's investigative demand "makes no secret of its connection to Musk's vindictive lawsuits," and "probes Media Matters' finances, editorial process, newsgathering activities, and affiliations with likeminded entities that monitor extremist content and other third parties," Media Matters said in the lawsuit filed in US District Court for the District of Columbia. Media Matters is a nonprofit journalism organization that has been targeted by Musk and Republicans for articles such as one showing that X placed advertisements next to pro-Nazi posts. Media Matters has faced probes from the Texas and Missouri attorneys general and a lawsuit filed by X. In the case involving Texas, a federal appeals court found in May that "Media Matters is the target of a government campaign of retaliation.". The FTC sent a civil investigative demand (CID) on May 20, "apparently seeking to revive the state government investigations that had been blocked by this Court," Media Matters said in its lawsuit yesterday. The CID's first substantive demand makes clear its connection to Musk's lawsuits, seeking 'all documents that Media Matters either produced or received in discovery in any litigation between Media Matters and X Corp. related to advertiser boycotts since 2023.'". The FTC demanded "all documents and communications relating to 13 entities, most of which had previously been the subject of Musk's public attention." The investigative demand "is overbroad and designed to be maximally burdensome on Media Matters," the lawsuit said. The FTC demand "lists nearly twice as many topics as the Texas and Missouri demands and asks for documents and information for a time period three times as long (more than six years compared to less than two years in the state CIDs)," Media Matters said. The CID constitutes a fishing expedition into the most sensitive areas of Media Matters' journalism and advocacy. It seeks to rifle through all of Media Matters' "financial statements" and "financial report[s]." It probes the core of the editorial process, seeking "the methodology by which Media Matters evaluates or categorizes any news, media, sources, platforms, outlets, websites, or other content publisher entities." It snoops into newsgathering activities, demanding "all communications" with third parties—such as members of the public—requesting that Media Matters label content for "hate speech" or "misinformation." And it intrudes into Media Matters' associations with others, seeking all communications with "any person connected to" groups that engage with these topics. Media Matters said it ramped up its reporting on Musk's social network after he bought Twitter and "began laying off key executives and content moderators responsible for removing hate speech and other violent rhetoric," eliminated policies that "served to protect users from misinformation and violent content," and "reinstated suspended accounts of known white supremacists and conspiracy theorists, while suspending the accounts of journalists who tracked his private air travel.". The lawsuit alleged that Media Matters' free speech rights are being violated "as state governments and now a federal agency have employed sweeping governmental powers to attempt to silence and harass an organization for daring to speak the truth." Media Matters said that under the First Amendment, it has "a privilege against disclosure of materials that would chill its constitutional rights." The FTC also violated "basic statutory requirements" in US law because the investigative demand "fails to identify the relevant 'conduct' or the 'alleged violation' that the FTC is investigating," the lawsuit said. The FTC is led by Chairman Andrew Ferguson. The FTC currently has only Republican commissioners because President Trump fired both Democrats. Media Matters said that claims of its involvement in an alleged advertiser boycott are baseless. Media Matters alleged that the civil investigative demand "constitutes a First Amendment retaliatory action in violation of Plaintiff's rights under the First Amendment of the US Constitution" and asked the court to issue an injunction to block the investigation. Media Matters also alleged a violation of the Fourth Amendment, which provides protection against unreasonable searches and seizures. The recent tension between Musk and Trump has not seemed to have any effect on the FTC investigation, Media Matters said.

title: Presidente de la Fed descarta recorte de tasas de interés en julio
content: Jerome Powell afirmó ante el Congreso que la economía de EE.UU. se mantiene "sólida", aunque reconoció que los aranceles podrían elevar los precios y afectar la actividad económica.
resumen:
El presidente de la Fed, Jerome Powell, indicó ante una comisión del Congreso que no considera oportuno reducir las tasas tan pronto como en julio, al señalar que la economía estadounidense sigue siendo "sólida" y que persiste la incertidumbre respecto al impacto de los aranceles y otras decisiones de política económica impulsadas por el gobierno.

Powell reconoció que el impacto de los aranceles sería menor al previsto en abril, pero advirtió que “es probable que los aumentos aplicados este año encarezcan los precios y limiten la actividad económica”.

Powell, cuyo mandato concluye en mayo de 2026, ha sido objeto de críticas por parte del mandatario estadounidense, quien ha reclamado una reducción de entre dos y tres puntos porcentuales en las tasas de referencia.

En 2024, la Fed redujo su tasa en un punto porcentual.

title: Powell advierte que subirán los precios y no bajará las tasas por ahora
content: El presidente de la Reserva Federal afirmó que los aranceles de Trump encarecerán los productos y golpearán la economía. La inflación repuntaría y no habrá recortes de tasas por ahora.
resumen: Jerome Powell, presidente de la Reserva Federal de Estados Unidos, advirtió este martes ante el Congreso que las recientes alzas de aranceles ordenadas por el presidente Donald Trump probablemente encarecerán los productos y ralentizarán la economía norteamericana. Powell afirmó que los precios van a subir y la Fed no se apresurará a recortar las tasas de interés. La tasa de referencia se mantiene entre 4,25% y 4,5%. Powell señaló que los economistas ya anticipan una nueva oleada de precios al alza debido al nuevo paquete arancelario. Powell también dejó la puerta abierta a moverse si la inflación cede o el mercado laboral se debilita, pero por ahora, no hay prisa. Trump criticó con dureza a Powell desde sus redes sociales. La decisión de Powell de no bajar las tasas tiene ramificaciones globales. Un dólar fuerte y tasas elevadas en EE. UU. suelen encarecer el financiamiento en mercados emergentes como Perú, restringir el crédito e incluso presionar al tipo de cambio. Si los aranceles de Trump frenan el comercio internacional, países exportadores —como el Perú— podrían sufrir caídas en ingresos por ventas externas.

title: Alarma por el acercamiento de Colombia al régimen de China
content: En mayo, Colombia dio dos pasos importantes en materia de política exterior con el objetivo de intensificar su compromiso con China. Durante la visita del presidente Gustavo Petro a Pekín el mes pasad ...
resumen:
En mayo, Colombia intensificó su compromiso con China. El presidente Gustavo Petro visitó Pekín para el Foro China-CELAC, donde Colombia se sumó a la Iniciativa del Cinturón y Ruta de la Seda (BRI). El Gobierno de Petro solicitó su adhesión al Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo del BRICS, aceptada el 19 de junio.

La adhesión a la BRI es una declaración política significativa en un panorama geopolítico en evolución.

El cultivo de coca aumentó un 10 % entre 2022 y 2023, mientras que la producción potencial de cocaína se disparó un 53 %. En la última década, el cultivo de coca se ha quintuplicado.

El comercio total entre Colombia y China pasó de 1200 millones de dólares en 2004 a 18 300 millones en 2024. El comercio con Estados Unidos alcanzó los 30 800 millones de dólares. Colombia exporta 14 300 millones de dólares a Estados Unidos, frente a 2400 millones de dólares a China.

La inversión extranjera directa (IED) china en Colombia fue de alrededor de 580 millones de dólares en los últimos tres años, muy por debajo de los 16 100 millones de dólares de IED estadounidense.

Entre 2018 y 2023, los bancos chinos financiaron aproximadamente 1400 millones de dólares en proyectos en Colombia, principalmente en infraestructura (más del 80 %), energía, manufactura y minería.

El presidente Petro busca "reducir el déficit comercial de Colombia con China, que asciende a 14 000 millones de dólares", e impulsar las exportaciones hasta los 10 000 millones de dólares.

Colombia debe ampliar su acceso a los mercados mundiales, diversificar sus exportaciones y enfocarse en Asia, incluyendo la adhesión al Acuerdo Integral y Progresista de Asociación Transpacífico (CPTPP).

title: Calma de precios, tormenta de fondo
content: La inflación global ha perdido fuerza, marcando el cierre de un ciclo de presión que comenzó con la pandemia y se amplificó por crisis sucesivas. Sin embargo, el alivio en los precios no se traduce en ...
resumen:
El tipo de cambio de hoy es de: Q7.68313 por US$1.00.
La inflación global ha perdido fuerza.
El alivio en los precios no se traduce en una recuperación sólida.
En Latinoamérica, la estabilidad convive con un crecimiento débil, presiones externas y un nuevo equilibrio comercial en disputa.
El fin del auge inflacionario redefine prioridades económicas.
El nuevo reto es no estancarse en medio de un entorno global más incierto.
Globalmente cayó al 4 % y se proyecta en 3 % para los próximos años.
Los países aún enfrentan riesgos por tasas altas y comercio fragmentado.
“Los consumidores han recuperado algo de poder adquisitivo, pero el entorno sigue siendo frágil”, comenta Paula Achury, analista económica de CABI.
Deben adaptarse a un mundo donde el dinamismo ya no es la norma y los ciclos son más volátiles.
El proceso de desinflación respondió a políticas restrictivas, ajustes de mercado y una transformación en la lógica del comercio global.
El covid, la guerra en Ucrania y los cuellos de botella logísticos alteraron los precios y provocaron una ola de inflación que alcanzó su pico en 2022.
Los bancos centrales elevaron sus tasas.
La Reserva Federal de EE. UU. aún mantiene la suya en 4.5 %.
“No estamos regresando al equilibrio anterior, sino entrando en un nuevo orden económico”, advierte Achury.
Los precios se estabilizan, pero los resultados son dispares.
Este año Guatemala (2 %), México (3.8) y Perú están dentro de sus metas.
Colombia continúa con la inflación más alta de la región: 5.2 %.
Rubros sensibles como educación (17 % en Colombia) y transporte todavía elevan el costo de vida en varios países.
Economías dolarizadas como Panamá, El Salvador y Ecuador presentan signos de deflación o precios estables.
El crecimiento se enfría en toda la región, sin llegar a recesión.
Latinoamérica crecerá apenas 2 % en 2025, según proyecciones de CABI.
La correlación inflacionaria con EE. UU. supera el 90 % en México, El Salvador y Panamá.
El Liberation Day y los nuevos aranceles elevan la incertidumbre sobre el comercio internacional y la competitividad regional.
Se necesitan respuestas de mediano plazo para no quedar atrapada entre riesgos externos y pasividad interna.
La Fed podría postergar cualquier baja de tasas si persisten los riesgos geopolíticos o un repunte de precios energéticos.
Las negociaciones comerciales entre EE. UU. y China siguen abiertas.
“El reto ahora es mantener la estabilidad sin frenar la recuperación”, concluye Achury.

title: Inflación ‘frena’ en primera quincena de junio: Se ubica en 4.51%, fuera del objetivo de Banxico
content: La inflación en la primera quincena de junio se desaceleró al 4.51 por ciento, en línea con la estimación mediana de los economistas en una encuesta de Bloomberg y por debajo del 4.62 por ciento del ...
resumen: La inflación en México se desaceleró a 4.51% en junio, por debajo del 4.62% de la quincena anterior. La inflación en la primera quincena de junio se desaceleró al 4.51 por ciento, en línea con la estimación mediana de los economistas en una encuesta de Bloomberg y por debajo del 4.62 por ciento del dato anterior. La cifra subyacente, que excluye artículos volátiles como alimentos y combustibles, subió al 4.20 por ciento desde el 4.15 por ciento de la lectura anterior, ubicándose ligeramente por encima del 4.16 por ciento estimado en la encuesta. Banxico implementó reducciones de medio punto porcentual en las tasas de interés en las últimas tres reuniones. La tasa de referencia se encuentra actualmente en el 8.5 por ciento. Banxico tiene como objetivo la inflación en el 3 por ciento, con una variación de un punto porcentual. El magro crecimiento económico, estimado en un 0.1 por ciento para este año, también ha sido considerado por la junta de gobierno como un factor que probablemente contribuirá a enfriar la inflación. Los analistas predijeron que la inflación para finales de año se desaceleraría al 3.9 por ciento y que la tasa de interés de fin de año de Banxico se establecería en el 7.5 por ciento.

title: Chile sube dos puestos en nuevo índice de competitividad global
content: Chile mejoró dos posiciones en el índice de competitividad global, hecho por la escuela de negocios suiza IMD, que comprende a 69 economías, encabezada por Suiza, Singapur y Hong Kong. A su vez, el ...
resumen: Chile subió dos posiciones en el índice de competitividad global, hecho por la escuela de negocios suiza IMD, que comprende a 69 economías, encabezada por Suiza, Singapur y Hong Kong. El país lidera el ranking a nivel Latinoamericano, seguido de Puerto Rico en el puesto 45 y Colombia en el 54. Argentina y Venezuela son los países de la región peor situados en el listado, con la posición 62 y 69. El top 10 incluye los siguientes estados: Suiza, Singapur, Hong Kong, Dinamarca, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, Taiwán, Irlanda, Suecia, Qatar y Países Bajos. Canadá (11) subió ocho puestos, Estados Unidos (13) bajó una posición, Lituana (21) y Malasia (23) mejoraron nueve y 11 puestos, respectivamente. Chile quedó por debajo de Indonesia y la India (40 y 41, respectivamente), y sobre Italia y Chipre, en los puestos 43 y 44. Chile destaca en la eficiencia gubernamental, manteniendo el lugar 30 a nivel global, con un desempeño que resalta en cuanto a finanzas públicas y legislación sobre negocios. En infraestructura, Chile cae tres puestos hasta la posición 48; en eficiencia empresarial, baja dos hasta el 43, y en desempeño económico sube 11 lugares hasta el 44. El instituto suizo apunta a enfrentar la guerra comercial de EEUU diversificando las exportaciones y dándoles valor añadido; incrementar la productividad de la mano de nuevas tecnologías y mejorar la seguridad pública fortaleciendo a las policías. También señalan la necesidad de mejoras en calidad de educación mediante el uso de inteligencia artificial, e incrementar el I+D, incluyendo proyectos colaborativos entre universidades, compañías y el sector público. El Centro de Competitividad Mundial del IMD lleva 37 años proporcionando datos y análisis sobre este tema. Se utiliza una perspectiva global, regional, subregional, económica y “humana”, utilizando datos externos duros y los resultados de una encuesta local realizada a ejecutivos de alto nivel en 69 economías globales.

title: La junta del Banco de la República se divide entre “palomas” y “halcones”
content: La junta del Banco de la República está dividida entre “halcones” cautelosos y “palomas” que piden bajar más la tasa, en medio de presiones del gobierno.
resumen:
La junta del Banco de la República (BdelaR) se divide entre “halcones monetarios” que abogan por la cautela y las “palomas monetarias” que exigen reducciones más agresivas en la tasa de intervención, reflejando la presión política del gobierno Petro sobre la autonomía del banco central.

El 31 de marzo, la junta mantuvo la tasa de intervención en 9,50%. Las expectativas de una reducción de al menos 50 puntos básicos (p.b.) generadas por los nuevos miembros Moisá y Giraldo, se basaban en que el gobierno tenía mayoría en la junta, pero Olga Lucía Acosta votó con independencia.

En la reunión del 30 de abril, la junta acordó por consenso una reducción de 25 p.b., quedando la tasa en 9,25%. El ministro de Hacienda aspiraba a una baja de 50 p.b. El presidente Petro criticó la leve disminución, acusando a la junta de paralizar la economía por razones políticas.

La junta consideró que la tasa alta se debe a que la inflación no se acerca a la meta del 3% y la economía crece por encima de lo esperado, además de las condiciones internacionales generadas por el aumento de aranceles por Trump.

Villar, director del BdelaR, dijo que la tasa de interés podrá ser inferior a la actual cuando la inflación esté alrededor del 3 por ciento.

Las minutas de las reuniones del 30 de abril y 31 de marzo muestran dos bloques en la junta: los “halcones monetarios” (mayoría) que prefieren reducir la tasa gradualmente y las “palomas monetarias” que proponen reducciones más amplias.

En la reunión de marzo 31, los “halcones monetarios” expresaron su deseo por continuar reduciendo la tasa de interés de política, sosteniendo que una decisión de esa naturaleza podría traducirse en presiones inflacionarias.

Las “palomas monetarias”, que votaron por una reducción de 50 p.b., resaltaron que la tendencia de reducción de la inflación básica ha continuado y propusieron una reducción por consenso de 25 p.b.

En la reunión del 30 de abril, los “halcones monetarios” advirtieron que el balance de riesgos parece estar sesgado hacia el alza de la trayectoria de la tasa de inflación, e hicieron un llamado al gobierno para que transmita señales claras de un ajuste fiscal.

Las “palomas monetarias” recordaron que la junta directiva ha mantenido congelada la tasa de política monetaria desde diciembre del año pasado, y destacaron que las expectativas de inflación no muestran una tendencia creciente.

Todos los miembros de la junta coincidieron en apoyar una decisión unánime. Los codirectores petristas —Moisá y Giraldo— y el ministro de Hacienda cedieron en sus pretensiones.

Según el centro de investigaciones económicas de Bancolombia, la inflación mensual de mayo seria de 0,48%, tal que el registro anual se aceleraría en 6 p.b. hasta 5,22%, 10 p.b. por encima de las expectativas del mercado. Fedesarrollo estimaba en marzo de 2025 que la tasa cerraría el año en 7,75%.

El déficit fiscal del gobierno fue de 6,8% del PIB en 2024 y llegó al 7,8% del PIB a junio de 2025, con una tendencia creciente.

En la reunión del 27 de junio, es probable que los codirectores más cautos opten por mantener la tasa en 9,25%. Las “palomas” seguirán presionando por una reducción de 50 p.b.

title: China y la guerra comercial: ¿Es el mejor momento para importar?
content: Recuerdo la primera vez que estuve en Guangzhou. Era 2014, y uno de mis primeros puntos de contacto — una empresaria colombiana que también había acudido a la feria — me contaba una anécdota sobre uno ...
resumen:
En 2014, el autor estuvo en Guangzhou y escuchó una anécdota sobre una estafa de más de 3 millones de euros en China.
Hoy, once años después, China sigue siendo un nuevo mundo.
En abril de este año, Grupo Dragón en México comenzó a llevar grupos mexicanos a la Feria de Cantón.
Los pagos a proveedores ahora se hacen por WeChat.
La volatilidad de la administración estadounidense actual hace difícil predecir los aranceles para 2025.
México vive un momento único, y China se ve obligada a fortalecer su relación con otros mercados.
Marcas como BYD, JAC, Chirey, MG han empezado a ganar terreno en México.
BYD anunció una inversión de 600 millones de dólares para una planta en el país.
Volvo comprometió inversiones de más de 1 billón.
Cada vez más emprendedores, marcas personales, y pequeños negocios están explorando importar desde China.
Se mencionan casos de éxito: una diseñadora de moda en Guadalajara, una pareja en San Luis Potosí, y un apasionado del pádel en el norte del país.
Grupo Dragón México busca acortar la distancia entre Latinoamérica y Asia.
El jueves 26 de junio a las 7:00 P.M. habrá una sesión informativa presencial sobre el viaje de la Feria de Cantón en las oficinas de Grupo Dragón en Chihuahua.
Para inscribirse a la sesión gratuita, se debe mandar un WhatsApp al 614 142 94 53.

title: La inflación en Canadá se estabiliza en el 1,7 % en mayo
content: Toronto (Canadá), 24 jun (EFE).- La inflación en Canadá se estabilizó en el 1,7 % interanual en mayo, la misma cifra que el mes anterior, gracias a la ralentización de los precios de la vivienda y de ...
resumen:
La inflación en Canadá se estabilizó en el 1,7 % interanual en mayo, la misma cifra que el mes anterior.
El organismo público Estadísticas Canadá (EC) informó.
Sin contar los precios de los productos energéticos, el índice de precios al consumo aumentó un 2,7 % en mayo tras un aumento del 2,9 % en abril.
De abril a mayo el aumento de la inflación fue del 0,6 %.
Los precios de alquiler subieron un 4,5 % comparado con los de mayo de 2024 (en abril la cifra fue del 5,2 %).
Los precios de la vivienda aumentaron un 3 % en mayo, cuatro décimas menos que el mes anterior.
Los precios del transporte aéreo cayeron un 10,1 %.
La gasolina tuvo una reducción del 15,5 % interanual.
En abril los precios de la gasolina se redujeron un 18,1%.
Los precios de los automóviles subieron un 4,9 %.
El Banco de Canadá podría anunciar el 30 de julio una reducción de los tipos de interés que en estos momentos se sitúan en el 2,75 %.

title: Operadores ven menos probabilidades de que la Fed baje las tasas en julio
content: 24 jun (Reuters) - Los operadores de futuros de tasas de interés de corto plazo veían el martes una menor probabilidad de un recorte de la Reserva Federal en julio, después de que el presidente de la ...
resumen: Los operadores de futuros de tasas de interés de corto plazo veían el martes una menor probabilidad de un recorte de la Reserva Federal en julio. Los precios de los contratos de futuros reflejan ahora sólo un 16% de probabilidad de un recorte de tasas de la Fed en julio, frente al 23% anterior. Los operadores siguen esperando un recorte en septiembre y otro en octubre o, con mayor probabilidad, en diciembre.

title: A war markets weren’t ready for: what US strikes on Iran mean for the global economy
content: US airstrikes on Iran raise fears of an oil supply shock and global inflation spike. Here’s what Trump’s latest move means for energy markets, interest rates, and global growth.
resumen:
The United States bombed Iran’s nuclear enrichment sites. Oil markets reacted sharply, with crude jumping 8.8% and fears of $130 oil if Hormuz is disrupted. The US remains insulated, while Europe, China, and oil importers face serious exposure to rising prices.

The airstrikes were targeted and precise. Trump hit three nuclear sites in Iran, after giving Israel space to weaken Tehran’s long-range missile capability. Iranian leaders have already made threats that they will retaliate. Iran’s economy is fragile enough to not be able to sustain a prolonged conflict with both the US and Israel. From the US side, there are no signs of a full-scale invasion or deployment of American troops so far. The majority of Americans oppose a war with Iran.

The Strait of Hormuz, a 21-mile-wide channel, carries 20% of the world’s daily oil supply and a massive chunk of liquefied natural gas. Iran has repeatedly threatened to close it even before the US attacks. Bloomberg Economics forecasts that a full shutdown of Hormuz would send oil past $130 per barrel. That could drive US inflation back to 4% and likely force the Federal Reserve to delay or cancel expected rate cuts. It would also crush growth in countries like Germany, Japan, India, and China, who are heavily exposed to energy imports. After the strikes, crude oil derivatives jumped 8.8%.

The US economy is better positioned than most. After the shale boom, America became a near-balanced oil trader, exporting and importing roughly the same amount. Russia could benefit from the chaos. China is now in a bind. Nearly all of Iran’s oil exports go to Beijing, and China has enjoyed steep discounts of around $6 per barrel cheaper than market prices. Europe is exposed too. If Qatar’s LNG exports are disrupted, which also flow through Hormuz, European gas prices could spike, especially in winter.

Saudi Arabia operates a 5 million barrel-per-day pipeline from its Gulf fields to the Red Sea. The UAE has a 1.5 million barrel-per-day line to Fujairah, bypassing Hormuz. Iraq, Kuwait, and Qatar, all 3 who are key exporters, have no viable alternatives.

There are three likely paths from here. In the most limited case, Iran retaliates with minor attacks on US bases or assets, and the conflict stays contained. Oil rises moderately, inflation ticks up, but central banks stay the course. In a mid-range scenario, Iran targets Gulf infrastructure or commercial tankers. The Strait of Hormuz becomes semi-operational. Oil spikes into the $110–$120 range. The Fed, ECB, and others freeze rate cuts, while global growth stalls. In the worst case, Hormuz shuts down entirely. Crude surges past $130. Inflation hits 4–5%. Interest rates stay high through 2025. Europe and Asia face energy crises. China scrambles to source oil at higher prices. Russia benefits. Markets spiral.

title: Por qué los bonos apuntan a ser el gran negocio para los inversores de cara al segundo semestre
content: Más allá de una eventual mejora en la calificación de Argentina, comprar títulos en pesos a tasas superiores al 30% anual se presenta como un gran negocio ...
resumen:
Según el Gurú de la City, comprar bonos en pesos a tasas superiores al 30% anual se presenta como un gran negocio.

El mundo podría no crecer a un ritmo superior al 3,0% anual.

El euro en 1,16 por dólar sigue aumentando.

El 9 de julio será una fecha clave, se definirán los aranceles comerciales de Estados Unidos con el mundo.

El 24 de junio el índice MSCI (Morgan Stanley Capital International) realiza su revisión anual de clasificación de mercados, y Argentina podría ser reclasificada.

El mercado argentino alcanzó un máximo en enero del año 2025 tocando el índice Merval los u$s2.400, luego hizo pie en los u$s1.400 y hoy cotiza en u$s1.783.

Las acciones con más volumen en el mercado internacional y que ejercen influencia significativa en nuestro mercado son Banco Macro, Grupo Financiero Galicia, YPF y Pampa Energía.

El bono AL35 vale u$s67,40 y si el riesgo país baja a los 550 puntos, este bono tendría que valer u$s75, lo que indica un potencial de suba de 11,2% en dólares, más el cupón de u$s2,06 que lo paga el 9 de julio próximo.

El Banco Central mantiene reservas por encima de los u$s40.000 millones.

El Banco Central tiene una base monetaria de $36 billones, de los cuales $22,5 billones es dinero en circulación.

La tesorería tiene en el Banco Central depositado un total de $16,8 billones.

El dólar mayorista el viernes cerró en $1.156,17, en el mes de junio este dólar cae el 3,3%.

La inflación esperada para los primeros 6 meses se ubicaría en el 15%.

title: Week Ahead: Markets Brace for Tariff Deadlines as Israel-Iran War Enters New Phase
content: Euro US Dollar, British Pound US Dollar, US Dollar Japanese Yen, US Dollar Swiss Franc. Read 's Market Analysis on Investing.com ...
resumen: The Israel-Iran war continues, but capital markets have barely reacted outside of oil. WTI rose by about 2.7% last week after a 13% rally the previous week, reaching levels not seen since early January. The average retail price of unleaded gasoline has risen by almost 2.5% this month. The price of gold fell by nearly 2% last week, its first weekly decline in three. The dollar rose against all of the G10 currencies. US tariff threats, with postponement of the so-called reciprocal tariffs coming to an end on July 9, continue to cast a long shadow. The recent doubling of the US steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% seems to make things more complicated. US real sector data continues to surprise on the downside, including May retail sales, industrial production, and housing starts. The FOMC indicated it is in no hurry to change policy, and despite Governor Waller suggesting a July cut is possible, the market does not believe it. September is a different story, and Fed funds futures are discounting around an 80% chance of a cut then. NATO has much to consider when it meets at the start of the new week. President Trump has said he will decide about increasing the US role against Iran in the next two weeks, by which time, Israel’s operation will be over or nearly so. The penetration depth of the "bunker buster" bomb is estimated to be about 200 feet (61 meters), and the Israeli intelligence estimates the facility may be as much as 300 feet below the surface. The economic diaries are fairly light in the week ahead. The flash PMI starts the new week. US CPI and PPI have stolen the thunder from the PCE deflators. Tokyo’s June CPI is expected to moderate slightly. Mexico’s central bank is expected to deliver another 50 bp cut. The end of the postponement of the so-called reciprocal tariffs is early July, and ahead of it, Trump has said he would send letters to countries, announcing the new bilateral tariffs. The new phase in the Israel-Iran war can become more impact for the dollar if the US takes a more direct role or if the war widens. The cost of insurance may be slowing activity in the Gulf of Hormuz more than Iranian forces. The market has little reason to react much to the survey data in the coming days, which include the preliminary PMI, several regional Fed surveys, and the Conference Board’s measure of consumer confidence. Given the tariffs, the May goods trade balance will be of interest. Weekly jobless claims will also draw attention given the recent rise in the four-week moving average to the highest since August 2023 and the elevated continuing claims. A surge of orders for Boeing (NYSE:BA) (303) in May will lift durable goods orders after a sharp 6.3% decline in April. The 1.5% decline in April orders excluding aircraft and defense was the largest drop since February 2023. Personal income and consumption data will help fine-tune Q2 GDP forecasts, which the Atlanta Fed says is tracking 3.4% and the median projection by economists in Bloomberg’s survey is 1.4%. Details for the CPI and PPI suggest the PCE deflator will tick up to 2.3% from 2.1% at the headline level and 2.6% from 2.5% at the core level. The Dollar Index consolidated last week at somewhat firmer levels. The trendline begins the new week near 98.65. The momentum indicators suggest a consolidative/corrective phase may be at hand. The five-day moving average looks poised to cross above the 20-day moving average in the coming days. The initial target may be in the 100.00-50 area. The euro benefits from being the un-cola to the dollar’s Coca-Cola (NYSE:KO). After a pause in the coming months, the swaps market is pricing in one more cut before the end of the year, which would bring the deposit rate to 1.75%. The markets may be more sensitive to the eurozone’s PMI than the US. The composite PMI slipped in April and May. May auto registrations, a proxy for sales are due. April showed the first increase year-over-year here in 2025. They rose 1.3%. Germany’s June IFO is due. The euro pulled back from $1.1630 reached on June 12, the highest level since October 2021. It recorded a low, a week later, near $1.1445, and found support slightly ahead of the 20-day moving average, which it has not traded below since the end of May. Nearby resistance is seen in the $1.1550-60 area. A consolidative/corrective phase can continue if the resistance holds. On the downside, a break of $1.1440 could see $1.1380 initially. China maintains a firm hand managing the yuan. Beijing is committed to maintaining the broad stability of the yuan against the dollar. China’s economy is struggling to sustain the momentum necessary to achieve its growth target and deflation continues to grip. The PBOC has been steadily lowering the dollar’s fix in recent weeks. Before the weekend, the fix was set at its lowest level in three months (CNY7.1695). The setting of the daily reference rate is among the most powerful tools at Chinese official disposal to manage the exchange rate. Since earlier this month, the greenback has been consolidating between roughly CNH7.1650 and CNH7.2000. The yen’s sensitivity to US interest rates has increased over the last few weeks. The rolling 30-day correlation of changes in the exchange rate and the US 10-year yield has risen to 0.48 from slightly below 0.10 a month ago. The Israel-Iran conflict did not spur a safe haven rally in the yen. Japan has the highest inflation in the G10, but the central bank is clearly reluctant to hike rates. Its bond and equity markets are the worst-performing in the G7 so far this year. Japan sees the latest employment figures and retail sales, but arguably the most important report is the Tokyo’s June CPI. Bank of Japan Governor Ueda rhetoric has been toned down. The swaps market sees the year-end target rate at almost 0.60%, down about 25 bp since late March. The dollar posted its biggest weekly advance of the year against the yen, almost 1.40%. It set the high for the month before the weekend, slightly above of JPY146.20. A move above the JPY146.30 area could spur a move toward JPY147.00-15 next. The momentum indicators are constructive. Initial support may be around JPY144.35. Sterling’s 7.6% gain this year against the dollar largely reflects the greenback’s weakness

Trump-appointed Fed Governor Christopher Waller's recent comments that interest rates could be reduced in July.

Analysts at ING said in a note to clients Friday.

title: It isn't just the Strait of Hormuz. Oil traders and global investors await Iran's response to U.S. strike.
content: Stock-market investors were rattled, and oil futures jumped, after Israel began its assault on Iran on June 12. West Texas Intermediate crude (CL.1), the U.S. benchmark, ended Friday at $74.93, losing ...
resumen: Iran's ability to choke off the Strait of Hormuz is a key question for investors. The potential for Iran to shut down shipping routes, particularly the strait, through which ships carrying roughly 20 million barrels a day of oil and oil products and 20% of the world's liquefied-natural-gas supply, has long served as a boogeyman for investors, oil traders, shippers and world leaders. Following President Donald Trump's decision to involve the U.S. directly in the Israel-Iran war Saturday by bombing Iranian nuclear sites, the threat is front and center. Rebecca Babin, senior energy trader and managing director at CIBC Private Wealth in New York, said that while odds of a full closure of the Strait of Hormuz remain below 50%, they are clearly higher than they were on Friday. The more immediate and likely scenario, she said, is increased harassment of vessels, through tactics like mining and boarding, that would raise transit times and shipping costs without a formal closure. The uncertainty is almost certain to spark a rally in crude when the market opens Sunday night. The market will be watching two key things: first, whether Iran's response includes energy infrastructure; and second, it if does, how long any disruptions could realistically persist, Babin said. News reports said Iran's parliament had endorsed closing the strait, though the body doesn't have the authority to implement, as such action would require approval from the Supreme Leader's council, Babin noted. If the Strait of Hormuz became non-navigable, it would constitute pretty much an unprecedented negative supply shock for the energy markets, at least in recent history, said Minna Kuusisto, chief analyst at Danske Bank in Copenhagen. Economists at Oxford Economics, in a June 20 report, warned that a "worst-case scenario" could see oil prices spike to $130 a barrel and shave 0.8 percentage points off of global gross domestic product. Flows through the Strait of Hormuz in 2024 and the first quarter of 2025 made up more than a quarter of total global seaborne oil trade and about a fifth of global oil and petroleum-product consumption, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said in a June 16 report. In addition, around 20% of global liquefied natural gas trade also moved through the strait in 2024. West Texas Intermediate crude (CL.1), the U.S. benchmark, ended Friday at $74.93, losing 22 cents. The S&P 500 SPX fell 0.2% on the week, ending Friday at 5,967.84, still just 2.9% below its record finish of Feb. 19. The U.S. has amassed a massive military presence in the Gulf and surrounding region, and a move by Iran against the strait would almost certainly trigger a significant military response, said Gregory Brew, senior analyst for Iran and energy at Eurasia Group. Increased Iranian harassment of tanker traffic is likely in coming days. Vice President J.D. Vance said any effort to disrupt shipping in the Strait of Hormuz would be "suicidal" for Iran. Danske Bank's Kuusisto said an attempt to close the strait would likely be viewed by Iran as its last option, noting that the strait is vital to the nation's ailing economy. Almost all of Iran's oil exports go to China.

title: Radiografía de los consumidores argentinos: 3 de cada 10 gastan más de lo que ganan y el 40% no puede ahorrar
content: Argentina 23/06/2025.- Las decisiones financieras cotidianas se volvieron una tarea estratégica en sí misma. Entre promociones, recortes, angustias emocionales y aspiraciones de estabilidad, la econom ...
resumen: En Argentina, tres de cada diez personas gastan más de lo que ganan y el 40% no puede ahorrar. Solo el 28% de la población logra guardar dinero, un porcentaje inferior al de países vecinos como Brasil, México y Colombia. El informe “Argentina, ¿cómo estás?” elaborado por Quiddity en el marco del Monitor Anual de Humor Social 2025 presenta datos que exponen una economía personal tensionada. El 30% de la población gasta más de lo que ingresa y el 40% no logra ahorrar nada mes a mes. En 2025, se prioriza recuperar productos resignados, como carnes y lácteos, y mantener ciertos gustos esenciales. El 42% de los argentinos elige viajar en temporada baja, el 27% planifica con antelación, y el 24% selecciona el transporte más económico. El 28% aprovecha actividades gratuitas en el destino. Los sectores de nivel socioeconómico (NSE) alto lideran la reactivación, mientras los NSE bajos destinan el 32% de su gasto a alimentos y bebidas. El 91% de las categorías creció gracias a descuentos, y el volumen vendido con promociones aumentó un 110% con relación al año anterior. El 69% de los encuestados del Monitor Anual de Humor Social 2025 mantiene expectativas de mejora para este año. El 85% quiere sostener a su familia y ahorrar. El 20% considera a la inflación como el principal problema. El 42% de los argentinos considera a la inseguridad como el problema más grave del país. El 42% de los argentinos declara sentirse ansioso o preocupado, y el 40% se reconoce agotado. El 90% de los trabajadores del país manifiestan síntomas de estrés, y más de una cuarta parte vincula esta sensación con la situación económica. El 88% de los argentinos admite darse un gusto para levantar el ánimo, aunque solo el 21% logra ahorrar. El valor del metro cuadrado en Buenos Aires subió 2% en dólares nominales pero cayó 11% en pesos ajustados por inflación. El 80% de los argentinos ha escuchado sobre los aranceles que el gobierno de Donald Trump impuso a productos de China y Europa. El 70% cree que esas medidas impactarán negativamente en la economía argentina, y el 50% considera que una eventual reelección de Trump empeorará el panorama local. El 73% de los argentinos afirma que es difícil hablar de política sin entrar en conflicto.

title: La peligrosa seducción del victimismo en la política
content: Atribuir la culpa a "otros" es una táctica política tentadora para ganar apoyo. Sin embargo, esta estrategia de victimismo a menudo empeora las cosas y daña a quienes busca proteger.
resumen:
El artículo trata sobre la estrategia política de atribuir la culpa a "otros" para ganar apoyo, conocida como victimismo.

Esta estrategia, aunque tentadora, a menudo empeora las cosas y daña a quienes busca proteger.

Se mencionan ejemplos como:

*   Políticos locales en ciudades indias que proponen cuotas de empleo para nativos, argumentando que los migrantes obtienen los mejores trabajos.
*   Políticos en Estados Unidos que aseguran que los estudiantes nativos meritorios no logran entrar a las mejores universidades.
*   La propuesta de la administración Trump de aplicar aranceles a la importación de iPhones para repatriar su fabricación.

Se argumenta que estas políticas pueden tener consecuencias negativas, como:

*   Disminución de la productividad y competitividad de las empresas.
*   Reducción de la calidad del alumnado en las universidades.
*   Aumento de los precios de los productos.

Se contrasta con el ejemplo de Singapur, donde un ministro defendió la atracción de estudiantes chinos, argumentando la necesidad de ser competitivos a nivel mundial.

Se concluye que, en lugar de culpar a otros, es mejor enfocarse en mejorar las capacidades y oportunidades de los rezagados.

El autor es Raghuram G. Rajan, ex gobernador del Banco de Reserva de la India y ex economista principal del Fondo Monetario Internacional.

title: JLR faces £1.6bn tariff blow in its US export market
content: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is preparing for a potential £1.6 billion hit in the wake of newly imposed US tariffs.
resumen:
Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is preparing for a potential £1.6 billion hit in the wake of newly imposed US tariffs.

The impact of these tariffs, introduced under US President Donald Trump’s administration, was confirmed by Tata Group chairman N Chandrasekaran at the company’s annual meeting on June 20.

Without intervention, JLR's tariff rate for exports to the US would have jumped from 2-2.5% to a punishing 27.5%.

However, thanks to a recent UK-US trade agreement signed in May, tariffs will now be capped at 10% - translating into an estimated £1.6 billion cost impact.

Even so, JLR, which derives over a quarter of its global sales from the US, said it is implementing mitigation measures to reduce the net impact to around £600 million.

It has forecast lower earnings for FY26, with operating margins expected to fall from 10% to between 5% and 7%.

Shares in JLR owner Tata Motors dropped 5.2% in early trading following the news, reported The Financial Express.

The company initially suspended shipments to the US following the introduction of the 25% blanket tariff on all foreign-made vehicles and said it was rerouting available stock to more accessible markets while it evaluates pricing strategies to absorb the increased costs.

Despite the pressure, JLR’s recent performance has been robust. Revenues reached £28.9 billion, with an EBIT margin of 8.5% and a pre-tax profit of £2.5 billion.

Chandrasekaran credited the ongoing success of the Range Rover and Defender franchises, as well as the local CKD (Completely Knocked Down) assembly of some models in India, for supporting growth.

The UK-built Range Rover line remains a cornerstone of the JLR brand, although the Defender, produced in Slovakia, is more vulnerable to US trade policy.

Slovakia, as part of the EU, will not benefit from the UK-specific trade deal, making those vehicles potentially subject to the full 25% tariff.

JLR said it is in ongoing talks with both the US and UK governments to navigate trade policy in a bid to minimise disruption.

title: Chinese Firms Fleeing US Exchanges As Trump Turns Up Heat On Beijing
content: Chinese companies are increasingly withdrawing their stocks from American exchanges as Washington intensifies regulatory scrutiny and political pressure on firms ...
resumen: Chinese companies are increasingly withdrawing their stocks from American exchanges as Washington intensifies regulatory scrutiny and political pressure on firms with ties to the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), The Wall Street Journal reported Monday. Since 2019, over 80 Chinese firms have delisted from the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and Nasdaq, with Chinese stocks now representing less than 2% of the total market capitalization on these stock exchanges, according to the WSJ. The decline coincides with broader efforts by the Trump administration to adopt a tougher stance towards China and crack down on its subversive economic tactics. While the number of Chinese initial public offerings in the U.S. increased in 2024, most were small firms raising an average of under $7 million, according to the WSJ. The NYSE hasn’t hosted a new Chinese listing since May 2024, when electric carmaker Zeekr went public. Government-owned companies like China Mobile, China Eastern Airlines and PetroChina went public on American stock exchanges in the 1990s and 2000s. In recent years, however, these companies have been forced to delist from U.S. exchanges, and today, no company explicitly owned by the Chinese government remains listed, according to the WSJ. Other Chinese firms have opted to delist themselves from U.S. exchanges instead of allowing U.S. regulators to scrutinize their accounting and business operations, the WSJ noted. The trend is unlikely to change, especially as the Republican-controlled Congress and the Trump administration have become more aggressive in efforts to combat Chinese economic warfare. The strategy was outlined in February by President Donald Trump as part of his America First Investment Policy, which asserted that China “exploits United States investors to finance and advance the development and modernization of its military.” Furthermore, in May, Rep. John Moolenaar, chairman of the House Select Committee on China, and Sen. Rick Scott of the Senate Committee on Aging, sent a letter urging the Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Paul Atkins to delist companies like Alibaba and Hesai with CCP links. “In the People’s Republic of China, no company is truly private. The CCP maintains sweeping authority over all firms — whether state-owned or nominally private — through legal mandates and political control mechanisms,” the letter read. “These entities benefit from American investor capital while advancing the strategic objectives of the CCP, supporting military modernization and gross human rights violations.” On trade, the Trump administration has imposed tariffs to address what it sees as unfair trade practices by the CCP that have contributed to a significant trade deficit with the country. In a recent meeting in London, U.S. representatives maintained a 55% tariff on Chinese imports, while China agreed to a 10% tariff on U.S. goods and pledged to relax its export controls on rare earth elements.

title: White House Faces Risk of Economic Fallout From Iran Strike
content: President Trump, aware of how high gas prices could affect his popularity, demanded on social media that the U.S. “KEEP OIL PRICES DOWN.” ...
resumen:
President Trump on Monday began to confront the potential economic blowback from his military strikes on Iran, which threatened to send oil and gas prices soaring at a moment when U.S. consumers are already facing significant financial strains.

Mr. Trump took to social media to push for more domestic drilling while demanding that companies “KEEP OIL PRICES DOWN.” Otherwise, the president said, they would be “PLAYING RIGHT INTO THE HANDS OF THE ENEMY.”“I’M WATCHING!” he added.

Global oil markets appeared relatively unfazed by the rising tensions between the two nations, just days after Mr. Trump dispatched U.S. bombers on a mission to disable three Iranian nuclear sites. Prices rose over the weekend but fell on Monday after Tehran launched retaliatory missile strikes against American bases abroad.

It remained unclear if Iran would continue to respond, or if its leaders might escalate the conflict, particularly by trying to block access to the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow waterway that serves as the critical entrance point to the Persian Gulf. The world ships substantial amounts of oil and liquefied natural gas through the passage, so any interruption to commerce could cause energy prices to surge globally.

A spike in energy costs could prove especially difficult for American consumers and businesses this summer, given that it could arrive at about the same time that Mr. Trump plans to revive his expansive, steep tariffs on nearly every U.S. trading partner. Many economists expect those levies to push up prices after years of high inflation.

Mr. Trump has not wavered in his plan to implement the tariffs again on July 9.

James Knightley, the chief international economist at ING, said that the uncertainties around geopolitics and trade threaten to “squeeze households’ spending power” in the coming months. He said that there was already “quite a lot of anxiety” about tariffs, and that the concern now was that there “could be another wave of pain for the consumer in the form of higher energy prices.”

A spike in oil prices would only add to the mounting political headaches facing Mr. Trump, who has promised to salve stubbornly high inflation dating back to the coronavirus pandemic.

Prices across the economy have remained relatively stable, according to the latest reading from the Consumer Price Index. But economists widely believe that inflation could pick up as soon as this summer, particularly once the president’s tariffs take full effect.

The Federal Reserve last week to leave interest rates unchanged for June.

Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chairman, told reporters on Wednesday that the central bank was “watching like everybody else is” to see how the conflict with Iran might affect prices.

On Monday, analysts at Goldman Sachs said that a disruption to the oil supply could cause a small but notable contraction in global economic growth while increasing inflation, depending on the duration of the conflict and the extent to which Iran opts to interfere with the Strait of Hormuz.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio urged Beijing over the weekend to take a stand against Iranian retaliation.

Mr. Trump and his top aides later suggested that they were closely watching energy prices, and they appeared to signal that they could take executive action if necessary to keep them from rising.

Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, told reporters.

On social media, Mr. Trump demanded that the Energy Department begin “NOW!!!” to increase domestic oil production. That prompted Energy Secretary Chris Wright to promise that the agency was “on it!”

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, told CNBC earlier Monday that other oil-producing countries had significant reserves at their disposal, giving them “a lot of room to adjust” if Iran retaliated in a way that affected oil and gas, causing prices to surge.

title: GT Voice: Tensions in Middle East may rattle global economy, require vigilance
content: At a time when the global economy and trade are facing mounting uncertainties, the recent US move to inflame tensions in the Middle East seems to be steering the world economy toward an even more ...
resumen: The recent US move to inflame tensions in the Middle East seems to be steering the world economy toward an even more precarious situation. The US has emerged as the biggest source of uncertainty that has repeatedly plunged the global economy into turmoil. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that the US strikes on Iran could potentially have broader impacts beyond energy channels, as global uncertainty escalates. The Strait of Hormuz, one of the most important trade routes for crude oil in the world, is facing the risk of being blocked. Some 20 million barrels per day of crude oil, or 20 percent of global consumption, flowed through the strait in 2024. Oil prices jumped on Monday to their highest since January. Goldman Sachs said in a note dated Sunday that Brent crude could briefly peak at $110 per barrel if oil flows through the critical waterway were halved for a month and remained down by 10 percent for the following 11 months. The sharp increase in oil prices could elevate the operating costs for energy-intensive industries and ripple through the supply chain. The US Dollar Index surged on Monday, at one point reaching 99.42, up 0.66 percent. The capital flight into such safe-haven assets could cause severe turbulence in financial markets. China has continuously improved its strategic petroleum reserve system, promoted a diversified distribution of energy imports, and accelerated the development of the new-energy industry. Washington's domestic and foreign policies, as well as its strikes on Iran, fully attest to this. Washington frequently takes unilateral actions in international affairs, disregarding international rules and the interests of other countries. All countries and regions are advised to remain vigilant and take proactive measures against US trade protectionism and its actions of deliberately creating chaos to profit from it.

title: Old allies, new agenda
content: — Future allies: The partnership opens the door for Canada to negotiate a bilateral agreement that could eventually allow Ottawa to bid on joint EU defense procurements. A working dinner and ...
resumen:
Prime Minister MARK CARNEY started his morning at a military cemetery in northern Belgium.

Foreign Affairs Minister ANITA ANAND and Defense Minister DAVID MCGUINTY will join Carney to sign the EU-Canada Security and Defense Partnership Agreement.

The agreement outlines new collaboration on crisis management, cyber and hybrid threats, military mobility, maritime security and defense industrial cooperation.

The May 27 throne speech read by KING CHARLES III in the Senate stated, “The world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War.”

Carney is meeting with European Commission President URSULA VON DER LEYEN and European Council President ANTÓNIO COSTA at the Canada-EU summit in Brussels.

Canada is approaching the summit as an opportunity to pivot towards a much closer relationship with the European Union as part of the diversification of economic and diplomatic relations.

The partnership opens the door for Canada to negotiate a bilateral agreement that could eventually allow Ottawa to bid on joint EU defense procurements.

The same Canadian official called it “the first step for Canada to participate in the ReArm Europe security action” noting that it provides up to 150 billion euros in EU loans to help EU member states increase their expenditure on common defense procurement.

Canada-U.S. Trade Minister DOMINIC LEBLANC says conversations between Ottawa and D.C. are focused — motivated by “the fact that there’s now a deadline set by the two leaders.”

The PM has asked KIRSTEN HILLMAN to stay on as Canada’s ambassador to Washington and play chief negotiator in the trade and security talks with the Trump administration.

President DONALD TRUMP and the PM started the clock at the G7 in Kananaskis — 30 days or bust.

Carney wants a deal to wipe out Trump’s tariffs — an “existential crisis” — and move on to other priorities in the “hinge moment” he keeps talking about.

POLITICO’s MEGAN MESSERLY tells us that with so many trade deadlines on the horizon, Canada is simply not a top priority.

A White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, tells Messerly the 30-day blitz was “a leader to leader thing” driven by Carney’s team.

On Tuesday, Carney makes way for the NATO leaders’ summit where he’ll briefly bask in the success of committing to the 2 percent-of-GDP target.

NATO allies have reached a deal on a new spending target of 5 percent of gross domestic product.

The new benchmark will split into a 3.5 percent contribution for military spending and 1.5 for spending in industry and infrastructure projects.

Trump said Friday he supports allies spending more but added the 5 percent target shouldn’t apply to the U.S., which is at 3.4 percent.

The cybersecurity industry is eyeing that 1.5 percent slice, hoping to profit on things like infrastructure and cybersecurity.

A Canadian official said that the investment that Canada is already making in infrastructure, in resilience, in everything that’s required in order for the defense to be delivered, would already take us through and past the 1.5 percent metric.

The G7 summit was roiled by claims that Trump wanted to “water down”. a declaration on Ukraine.

A Canadian official was asked during a Saturday briefing for reporters if the NATO statement will name Russia as a “threat” to the alliance.

A Canadian official said, “There are a very substantial number of allies, including Canada, that are very strongly of the view that Russia ought to be identified as a threat.”

The statement will express solidarity with Ukraine and underscore the importance of Ukraine security to transatlantic security.”

The Senate resumes sitting Wednesday when it will get the next chance to approve the government’s bill on internal trade, labor mobility and building big projects.

The House of Commons passed the sweeping “nation-building” bill Friday with Conservative support, and looks on track to become law by Canada Day, as the PM has pledged.

Carney said he will hold working sessions and public roundtables with First Nations leaders on July 17 with Inuit and Métis rights-holders, leadership and experts.

He also announced additional funding to help First Nations, Inuit and Métis participate.

Carney wants everyone to remember the underlying reason for all of this is U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

The PM is in Brussels. At 5 p.m. local time, he’s scheduled to arrive at the Canada-European Union Summit.

At 1 p.m. Ontario Deputy Premier SYLVIA JONES will hold a presser with JANE PHILPOTT, chair of the Primary Care Action Team.

JOHN MCCALLUM, (1950-2025) — Remembrances flowed in for the former Liberal Cabinet minister, and former ambassador to China, who died Saturday at age 75.

As an MP, McCallum served in numerous portfolios, including defense, veterans affairs and national revenue.

Before entering politics, he was dean of arts at McGill University and the chief economist for Royal Bank of Canada.

His most revered political accomplishment was burning the midnight oil at the immigration department to help make good on a 2015 Liberal campaign promise to bring almost 45,000 Syrian refugees to Canada.

Prime Minister MARK CARNEY called McCallum an inspiration, mentor and a friend.

Former Prime Minister JUSTIN TRUDEAU fondly recalled the Syrian refugee resettlement saying, McCallum “made it happen despite real challenges in an unpredictable time.”

Foreign Affairs Minister ANITA ANAND expressed gratitude for his “generosity, warmth and wisdom.”.

Birthdays: LAUREEN HARPER; JUDY FOOTE, Newfoundland and Labrador’s 14th and first female lieutenant governor; Conservative MP KELLY MCCAULEY and DAN PUJDAK of Blackbird Strategies.

Spotted: Tributes in the Senate last week to Sen. JUDITH G. SEIDMAN, who retires Sept. 1.

Movers and shakers: Just before the votes on Bill C-5, the PM announced the changes in the senior public service, noting: “A stronger Canada depends on a strong and effective public service – one that is focused on execution, delivery, and impact.”

JEAN-FRANÇOIS TREMBLAY becomes “senior official” at the Privy Council Office.

MOLLIE JOHNSON will take over as deputy minister of environment and climate change.

NANCY HAMZAWI was named president of the Public Health Agency of Canada.

ALISON O’LEARY will be associate deputy minister of finance.

Fisheries and Oceans Associate Deputy Minister KAILI LEVESQUE has been enlisted to support the secretary of state of nature.

MARK SCHAAN will support Minister of Artificial Intelligence and Digital Innovation EVAN SOLOMON, in addition to his role as deputy secretary to the Cabinet (Artificial Intelligence) in the Privy Council Office.

MIKE PEMBERTON is the new leader of the Yukon Liberal Party and the territory’s next premier.

NIK NANOS has been officially installed as chancellor of Carleton University.

Farewells: HEATHER JEFFREY

title: Can China build on eased trade tensions with US amid Trump’s many distractions?
content: Momentum may stall after London talks, but Beijing should advance a steady, leader-driven process, observers say.
resumen:
Mientras que las conversaciones entre Estados Unidos y China en Londres a principios de este mes sugirieron que Beijing tenía la ventaja negociadora sobre los otros principales socios comerciales de Washington, los observadores advierten que China puede necesitar moderar las expectativas de una restauración de los intercambios de alto nivel.

Las prioridades contrapuestas del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump, tanto a nivel nacional como internacional, podrían distraer a su administración de la necesidad apremiante de establecer un acuerdo duradero sobre las relaciones comerciales entre Estados Unidos y China, dijeron.

Pero si bien la administración Trump se encuentra en las primeras etapas de la formulación de su política hacia China, Beijing debería avanzar en un proceso liderado por líderes para estabilizar los lazos bilaterales, sentando las bases para un acuerdo comercial antes de una posible cumbre.

Sourabh Gupta, especialista en políticas senior del Instituto de Estudios China-América en Washington, dijo que el marco alcanzado en Londres fue "una genuina desescalada de las tensiones comerciales".

"Al menos, así es como las dos partes lo imaginan", dijo, señalando que el marco esencialmente marcó un regreso al acuerdo de Ginebra del mes pasado, con ambas partes teniendo "un interés personal en llegar a un 'sí' en un acuerdo comercial".

Según Gupta, el resultado de las conversaciones, junto con la primera llamada entre el presidente chino Xi Jinping y Trump desde que este último comenzó su segundo mandato, ha colocado a China como "líder" en las negociaciones de Washington con los principales socios comerciales.

Si bien el marco de Londres representa una tregua temporal en lugar de un acuerdo integral, ningún otro socio comercial de Estados Unidos ha asegurado un acuerdo comparable, a pesar de las negociaciones paralelas con la Unión Europea, Japón, Corea del Sur, Canadá, India y otros.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet with their counterparts in Geneva. Trump wrote on his social media account on Friday morning, referring to Scott Bessent, his Treasury chief. The Republican president also called on China to open its markets to the U.S. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt clarified that such a potential move would not come "unilaterally" ahead of talks. Trump said he "could" lower the 145% rate charged on Chinese goods if the weekend talks go well.

title: Planning around global tensions
content: The Iran-Israel conflict may drive up oil prices and shipping costs, factors that budget makers had assumed would remain ...
resumen:
For import-dependent Pakistan, another conflict in the neighbourhood is deeply alarming. Pakistan may be among the countries hardest hit by the ongoing Iran-Israel war, facing significant economic and social repercussions. Any widening of the conflict would multiply Pakistan’s economic and diplomatic challenges.

President Donald Trump promised not to directly target Iran for the next two weeks, sparking hopes for a ceasefire and a peace deal.

The timing of the war, breaking out as Pakistan was finalising its budget, has compounded challenges. It diverted focus from pressing domestic issues and disrupted key assumptions underlying the budget proposals.

Khurram Schehzad, a member of Prime Minister Shehbaz’s economic team, stated that budget planning is anchored in prudence, with built-in buffers to absorb external shocks, and there is no immediate need to revise projections unless global conditions deteriorate significantly.

The Iran-Israel conflict may drive up oil prices and shipping costs. Analysts agree that a prolonged conflict would almost certainly lead to significant increases. This would derail inflation targets, revive fiscal and current account pressures, strain foreign exchange reserves and weaken the rupee. It could also force the government to revisit or roll back revenue measures such as higher petroleum development levy and the proposed carbon tax.

Inflation, which has fallen from historic highs of 38 per cent in May 2023 to just 3.5pc by May 2025, is likely to surge again.

The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) opted to steady rates in its monetary policy announcement last Monday.

The investment rate is unlikely to pick up, further undermining GDP growth projections.

Dr Manzoor Ahmed, a trade expert and former Pakistan World Trade Organisation representative, said: “The immediate impact is a sharp rise in global oil prices, up nearly 7pc since hostilities began. For Pakistan, where imported energy accounts for 30pc of total imports, this is deeply concerning. Past crises, such as the 2008 Iraq war and 2022 Russia-Ukraine conflict, saw oil prices soar above $120 to $145 per barrel. If Iran closes the Strait of Hormuz, which handles a fifth of global oil trade, it would disrupt supply chains, spike freight and insurance costs, risk pushing major economies into recession. Such shocks would hit Pakistan’s exports and derail any fragile progress towards economic stability and growth.”

Mr Schehzad said: “While regional tensions warrant close monitoring, it’s important not to overstate their immediate economic impact on Pakistan.”

Younus Dagha, former federal secretary and Sindh minister and current Chairman of the Policy Research Advisory Council (PRAC), noted: “Wars and natural disasters can’t be fully accounted for during budget planning; provisions are made as events unfold. It’s impossible to predict whether the Iran-Israel conflict will end quickly or drag on for months. While PRAC has already questioned the growth and revenue targets in the 2025–26 budget, it remains too early to gauge how this crisis on our western border will affect the economy.”

Ehsan Malik, CEO of the Pakistan Business Council, said: “Middle East tensions are pushing up fuel costs and threatening supply through the Strait of Hormuz, which carries 15pc of global oil and 20pc of gas. The region supplies half the world’s energy. Brent crude has climbed to a five-month high at $77.2 per barrel. For Pakistan, which spends about $20 billion on oil and gas [a third of imports], a 7–10pc price hike could strain the external account by $1.5–2bn and weaken the rupee, especially against the euro. Higher fuel costs will fuel inflation, but fiscal space is too tight to lower the Petroleum Development Levy. There’s no need to delay the budget; any adjustments can be made through mini-budgets if needed.”

The ongoing conflict risks further destabilising Balochistan, which hosts some of the country’s largest China-Pakistan Economic Corridor infrastructure projects and rich mineral deposits. Pakistan has already tightened controls on the Afghanistan border and, following the Israel attack, sealed the key entry and exit points along its 560 miles border with Iran. Balochistan shares a 724-miles border with Afghanistan.

Majyd Aziz, former president of the Karachi Chamber of Commerce and Industry remarked, “Lessons must be learned from Yemen’s recent Suez Canal blockade — Pakistan typically holds only three weeks of oil reserves. Another risk is a potential influx of Iranian refugees into Balochistan. Furthermore, disruptions in sea routes could hamper exports, triggering factory closures if shipping lines reroute vessels.”

title: Strait of Hormuz: US urges China to stop Iran from blocking critical shipping lane
content: Analysts have said Iran may opt to retaliate to Washington's early Sunday attack by shutting the Strait, a waterway through which one-fifth of global oil output passes ...
resumen:
US Secretary of State Marco Rubio urged China Sunday to help deter Iran from shutting down the Strait of Hormuz.
Analysts have said Iran may opt to retaliate to Washington's early Sunday attack by shutting the Strait, a waterway through which one-fifth of global oil output passes.
Rubio said, "I encourage the Chinese government in Beijing to call them about that because they heavily depend on the Strait of Hormuz for their oil," on Fox News.
Rubio added, "If they do that, it will be another terrible mistake. It's economic suicide for them if they do it, and we retain options to deal with that."
Rubio said, "But other countries should be looking at that as well, it would hurt other countries' economies a lot worse than ours. It would be, I think, a massive escalation that would merit a response. Not just by us but from others."
Iran has threatened bases used by the US military, with an advisor to Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei saying they will be considered a "legitimate target for our armed forces."
China has joined Russia and a chorus of Arab states in condemning the US attacks, saying that they "escalate tensions in the Middle East."

title: Investors brace for oil price spike, rush to havens after US bombs Iran nuclear sites
content: A key concern for markets would center around the potential impact of the developments in the Middle East on oil prices and thus on inflation.
resumen:
A U.S. attack on Iranian nuclear sites on Saturday is expected to cause market reactions, potentially increasing oil prices and triggering a rush to safety.

U.S. President Donald Trump called the attack "a spectacular military success" and said Iran's "key nuclear enrichment facilities have been completely and totally obliterated". He said the U.S. military could go after other targets in Iran if the country did not agree to peace.

Iran said it reserves all options to defend itself, and warned of "everlasting consequences". Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi said Tehran was weighing its options for retaliation and would consider diplomacy only after carrying out its response.

Mark Spindel, chief investment officer at Potomac River Capital, said oil will open higher. He added that the uncertainty is going to blanket the markets, and it's going to raise uncertainty and volatility, particularly in oil.

Ether was down 8.5% on Sunday, taking losses since the first Israeli strikes on Iran on June 13 to 13%.

A key concern for markets would center around the potential impact of the developments in the Middle East on oil prices and thus on inflation. A rise in inflation could dampen consumer confidence and lessen the chance of near-term interest rate cuts.

Saul Kavonic, a senior energy analyst at equity research firm MST Marquee in Sydney, said Iran could respond by targeting American interests in the Middle East, including Gulf oil infrastructure in places such as Iraq or harassing ship passages through the Strait of Hormuz.

The Strait of Hormuz lies between Oman and Iran and is the primary export route for oil producers such as Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Iraq and Kuwait.

Kavonic said this could set us on a path towards $100 oil if Iran responds as they have previously threatened to.

Global benchmark Brent crude futures have risen as much as 18% since June 10, hitting a near five-month high of $79.04 on Thursday.

Jamie Cox, managing partner at Harris Financial Group, said oil prices would likely spike before leveling off in a few days as the attacks could lead Iran to seek a peace deal with Israel and the United States.

Economists warn that a dramatic rise in oil prices could damage a global economy already strained by Trump's tariffs.

During past eruptions of Middle East tensions, including the 2003 Iraq invasion and the 2019 attacks on Saudi oil facilities, stocks initially languished but soon recovered to trade higher in the months ahead.

On average, the S&P 500 slipped 0.3% in the three weeks following the start of conflict, but was 2.3% higher on average two months following the conflict, according to data from Wedbush Securities and CapIQ Pro.

In the most severe case, global oil prices jump to around $130 per barrel, driving U.S. inflation near 6% by the end of this year, Oxford said in the note.

In the event of U.S. direct engagement in the Iran-Israel war, the dollar could initially benefit from a safety bid, analysts said.

Steve Sosnick, chief market strategist at IBKR in Greenwich, Connecticut, said a flight to safety would signal yields going lower and the dollar getting stronger.

Jack McIntyre, portfolio manager for global fixed income at Brandywine Global Investment Management in Philadelphia, said it was uncertain whether U.S. Treasuries would rally after the U.S. attack, largely due to the market's hypersensitivity to inflation.

General Secretary To Lam’s swift congratulatory call with Trump after his election victory in April 2025.
